dn1:1.1.1.comm: Tradition holds that these were the words spoken by Ānanda when reciting the Suttapiṭaka at the First Council following the Buddha’s death. In fact it is a tag signifying that the text has been passed down through oral tradition and the speaker was not present at the events (DN 5:21.10, MN 127:17.4). | This sutta with its commentary was translated by Bhikkhu Bodhi in his The All-Embracing Net of Views.

dn1:1.1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā antarā ca rājagahaṃ antarā ca nāḷandaṃ addhānamaggappaṭipanno hoti mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi.
dn1:1.1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was traveling along the road between Rājagaha and Nāḷandā together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants.
dn1:1.1.2.comm: By convention, suttas do not specify the date, so we have scant internal chronology. | Walk about fifteen kilometers north from Rājagaha (modern Rajgir) to reach Nāḷandā. | “Mendicant” is a literal translation of bhikkhu, one who goes for alms.

dn1:1.1.3.pli: Suppiyopi kho paribbājako antarā ca rājagahaṃ antarā ca nāḷandaṃ addhānamaggappaṭipanno hoti saddhiṃ antevāsinā brahmadattena māṇavena.
dn1:1.1.3.eng: The wanderer Suppiya was also traveling along the same road, together with his resident pupil, the student Brahmadatta.
dn1:1.1.3.comm: A “wanderer” (paribbājaka) was a homeless religious renunciate—male or female—who wandered seeking alms. Kauṭilya describes their lifestyle as “mastery of the senses, abstaining from ritual activities, living without possessions, abandoning attachments, practicing mendicancy, residing in the wilderness but not in a single place, and purifying himself internally and externally” (Arthaśāstra 1.3.12, Olivelle’s translation). | “Resident pupil” (or elsewhere just “pupil”) is antevāsi, a live-in apprentice of a master. | “Student” (māṇava) is a young man who was learning the Vedas from a master.

dn1:1.1.4.pli: Tatra sudaṃ suppiyo paribbājako anekapariyāyena buddhassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṅghassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati;
dn1:1.1.4.eng: Meanwhile, Suppiya criticized the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in many ways,
dn1:1.1.4.comm: Today these are called the Triple Gem that makes up the Buddhist religion; however they are not known by that term in the early texts.

dn1:1.1.5.pli: suppiyassa pana paribbājakassa antevāsī brahmadatto māṇavo anekapariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṅghassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.
dn1:1.1.5.eng: but his pupil Brahmadatta praised them in many ways.
dn1:1.1.5.comm: While the disagreement of student and teacher signifies their confusion, it also represents the diversity of views within the brahmanical caste and the openness with which a student could disagree with their teacher.

dn1:1.1.6.pli: Itiha te ubho ācariyantevāsī aññamaññassa ujuvipaccanīkavādā bhagavantaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhā honti bhikkhusaṅghañca.
dn1:1.1.6.eng: And so both tutor and pupil followed behind the Buddha and the Saṅgha of mendicants directly contradicting each other.

dn1:1.2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ rājāgārake ekarattivāsaṃ upagacchi saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena.
dn1:1.2.1.eng: Then the Buddha took up residence for the night in the royal rest-house in Ambalaṭṭhikā together with the Saṅgha of mendicants.
dn1:1.2.1.comm: Ambalaṭṭhikā means “place of mango saplings”. It was a rest-house set up by the king of Rājagaha about a day’s journey from the capital. It must have been sizable.

dn1:1.2.2.pli: Suppiyopi kho paribbājako ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ rājāgārake ekarattivāsaṃ upagacchi antevāsinā brahmadattena māṇavena.
dn1:1.2.2.eng: And Suppiya and Brahmadatta did likewise.

dn1:1.2.3.pli: Tatrapi sudaṃ suppiyo paribbājako anekapariyāyena buddhassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṅghassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati;
dn1:1.2.3.eng: There too, Suppiya criticized the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in many ways,

dn1:1.2.4.pli: suppiyassa pana paribbājakassa antevāsī brahmadatto māṇavo anekapariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṅghassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.
dn1:1.2.4.eng: but his pupil Brahmadatta praised them in many ways.

dn1:1.2.5.pli: Itiha te ubho ācariyantevāsī aññamaññassa ujuvipaccanīkavādā viharanti.
dn1:1.2.5.eng: And so both tutor and pupil kept on directly contradicting each other.

dn1:1.3.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ paccuṭṭhitānaṃ maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ayaṃ saṅkhiyadhammo udapādi:
dn1:1.3.1.eng: Then several mendicants rose at the crack of dawn and sat together in the pavilion, where the topic of judgmentalism came up:
dn1:1.3.1.comm: Saṅkhiyadhamma is a unique term. The commentary glosses it as kathādhamma, following which it has been translated as “conversation” or “trend of conversation”. But saṅkhā means “appraisal, assessment, evaluation, measuring, calculating”, and here the subject of discussion is the different ways the two parties assess or judge the Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha. Compare the “appraisal” of the Buddha at DN 19:19.2.

dn1:1.3.2.pli: “acchariyaṃ, āvuso, abbhutaṃ, āvuso, yāvañcidaṃ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sattānaṃ nānādhimuttikatā suppaṭividitā.
dn1:1.3.2.eng: “It’s incredible, reverends, it’s amazing how the diverse convictions of sentient beings have been well deciphered by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
dn1:1.3.2.comm: Adhimutti is something that has been decided, a conviction or belief.

dn1:1.3.3.pli: Ayañhi suppiyo paribbājako anekapariyāyena buddhassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṅghassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati;
dn1:1.3.3.eng: For this Suppiya criticizes the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in many ways,

dn1:1.3.4.pli: suppiyassa pana paribbājakassa antevāsī brahmadatto māṇavo anekapariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṅghassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.
dn1:1.3.4.eng: while his pupil Brahmadatta praises them in many ways.

dn1:1.3.5.pli: Itihame ubho ācariyantevāsī aññamaññassa ujuvipaccanīkavādā bhagavantaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhā honti bhikkhusaṅghañcā”ti.
dn1:1.3.5.eng: And so both tutor and pupil followed behind the Buddha and the Saṅgha of mendicants directly contradicting each other.”

dn1:1.4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ imaṃ saṅkhiyadhammaṃ viditvā yena maṇḍalamāḷo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Nisajja kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
dn1:1.4.1.eng: When the Buddha found out about this discussion on judgmentalism among the mendicants, he went to the pavilion, where he sat on the seat spread out and addressed the mendicants,
dn1:1.4.1.comm: This would have been an open air pavilion in the rest-house. By convention, when a teacher or other respected person is to sit, a sitting mat is spread out or made ready for them.

dn1:1.4.2.pli: “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā sannipatitā, kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
dn1:1.4.2.eng: “Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”
dn1:1.4.2.comm: The very first words of the Buddha in the Suttapiṭaka: he asks to hear what others are saying.

dn1:1.4.3.pli: Evaṃ vutte, te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn1:1.4.3.eng: The mendicants told him what had happened, adding,
dn1:1.4.3.comm: Here and in similar passages the Pali repeats all and I abbreviate.

dn1:1.4.4.pli: “idha, bhante, amhākaṃ rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ paccuṭṭhitānaṃ maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ayaṃ saṅkhiyadhammo udapādi:

dn1:1.4.5.pli: ‘acchariyaṃ, āvuso, abbhutaṃ, āvuso, yāvañcidaṃ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sattānaṃ nānādhimuttikatā suppaṭividitā.

dn1:1.4.6.pli: Ayañhi suppiyo paribbājako anekapariyāyena buddhassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṅghassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati;

dn1:1.4.7.pli: suppiyassa pana paribbājakassa antevāsī brahmadatto māṇavo anekapariyāyena buddhassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṅghassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.

dn1:1.4.8.pli: Itihame ubho ācariyantevāsī aññamaññassa ujuvipaccanīkavādā bhagavantaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhā honti bhikkhusaṅghañcā’ti.

dn1:1.4.9.pli: Ayaṃ kho no, bhante, antarākathā vippakatā, atha bhagavā anuppatto”ti.
dn1:1.4.9.eng: “This was our conversation that was unfinished when the Buddha arrived.”

dn1:1.5.1.pli: “Mamaṃ vā, bhikkhave, pare avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, dhammassa vā avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, saṅghassa vā avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, tatra tumhehi na āghāto na appaccayo na cetaso anabhiraddhi karaṇīyā.
dn1:1.5.1.eng: “Mendicants, if others criticize me, the teaching, or the Saṅgha, don’t make yourselves resentful, bitter, and exasperated.
dn1:1.5.1.comm: The phrasing here is somewhat unusual and specific. They “should not do” what creates bitterness (i.e. judging others). Compare MN 22, where the same phrases are used. In the Buddha’s case, it has the neutral hoti, while for the mendicants it uses karaṇīya, as here.

dn1:1.5.2.pli: Mamaṃ vā, bhikkhave, pare avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, dhammassa vā avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, saṅghassa vā avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, tatra ce tumhe assatha kupitā vā anattamanā vā, tumhaṃ yevassa tena antarāyo.
dn1:1.5.2.eng: You’ll get angry and upset, which would be an obstacle for you alone.
dn1:1.5.2.comm: Complaining about others does not hurt them, only the one who gets upset.

dn1:1.5.3.pli: Mamaṃ vā, bhikkhave, pare avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, dhammassa vā avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, saṅghassa vā avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, tatra ce tumhe assatha kupitā vā anattamanā vā, api nu tumhe paresaṃ subhāsitaṃ dubbhāsitaṃ ājāneyyāthā”ti?
dn1:1.5.3.eng: If others were to criticize me, the teaching, or the Saṅgha, and you got angry and upset, would you be able to understand whether they spoke well or poorly?”
dn1:1.5.3.comm: Equanimity is a prerequisite for evaluating facts.

dn1:1.6.1.pli: “Mamaṃ vā, bhikkhave, pare avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, dhammassa vā avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, saṅghassa vā avaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, tatra tumhehi abhūtaṃ abhūtato nibbeṭhetabbaṃ:
dn1:1.6.1.eng: “If others criticize me, the teaching, or the Saṅgha, you should explain that what is untrue is in fact untrue:

dn1:1.6.2.pli: ‘itipetaṃ abhūtaṃ, itipetaṃ atacchaṃ, natthi cetaṃ amhesu, na ca panetaṃ amhesu saṃvijjatī’ti.
dn1:1.6.2.eng: ‘This is why that’s untrue, this is why that’s false. There’s no such thing in us, it’s not found among us.’

dn1:1.6.3.pli: Mamaṃ vā, bhikkhave, pare vaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, dhammassa vā vaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, saṅghassa vā vaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, tatra tumhehi na ānando na somanassaṃ na cetaso uppilāvitattaṃ karaṇīyaṃ.
dn1:1.6.3.eng: If others praise me, the teaching, or the Saṅgha, don’t make yourselves thrilled, elated, and excited.

dn1:1.6.4.pli: Mamaṃ vā, bhikkhave, pare vaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, dhammassa vā vaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, saṅghassa vā vaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, tatra ce tumhe assatha ānandino sumanā uppilāvitā tumhaṃ yevassa tena antarāyo.
dn1:1.6.4.eng: You’ll get thrilled, elated, and excited, which would be an obstacle for you alone.

dn1:1.6.5.pli: Mamaṃ vā, bhikkhave, pare vaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, dhammassa vā vaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, saṅghassa vā vaṇṇaṃ bhāseyyuṃ, tatra tumhehi bhūtaṃ bhūtato paṭijānitabbaṃ:
dn1:1.6.5.eng: If others praise me, the teaching, or the Saṅgha, you should admit that what is true is in fact true:

dn1:1.6.6.pli: ‘itipetaṃ bhūtaṃ, itipetaṃ tacchaṃ, atthi cetaṃ amhesu, saṃvijjati ca panetaṃ amhesū’ti.
dn1:1.6.6.eng: ‘This is why that’s true, this is why that’s correct. There is such a thing in us, it is found among us.’

dn1:1.7.1.pli: Appamattakaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, oramattakaṃ sīlamattakaṃ, yena puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.7.1.eng: When an ordinary person speaks praise of the Realized One, they speak only of trivial, trifling details of mere ethics.
dn1:1.7.1.comm: Ethics (or morality or virtue, sīla) is important, but it pales in comparison with the higher dimensions of the Buddha’s path. For an example of this kind of praise see MN 77:8.1. | The Buddha often referred to himself as “the Realized One” (tathāgata).

dn1:1.7.2.pli: Katamañca taṃ, bhikkhave, appamattakaṃ oramattakaṃ sīlamattakaṃ, yena puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya?
dn1:1.7.2.eng: And what are the trivial, trifling details of mere ethics that an ordinary person speaks of?
dn1:1.7.2.comm: Here the Buddha lays out in detail the ethical conduct for mendicant followers.

dn1:1.8.1.pli: ‘Pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo nihitadaṇḍo, nihitasattho, lajjī, dayāpanno, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharatī’ti—
dn1:1.8.1.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up killing living creatures. He has renounced the rod and the sword. He’s scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.’
dn1:1.8.1.comm: The first and most important precept. It is not just the negative injunction to avoid killing, but also the positive injunction to have compassion for all creatures. | The Buddha is called “the ascetic Gotama” by non-Buddhists.

dn1:1.8.2.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.8.2.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.8.2.comm: An “ordinary person” (puthujjana) is anyone who has not, at minimum, entered the path to stream-entry.

dn1:1.8.3.pli: ‘Adinnādānaṃ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī, athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharatī’ti—
dn1:1.8.3.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up stealing. He takes only what’s given, and expects only what’s given. He keeps himself clean by not thieving.’

dn1:1.8.4.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.8.4.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.8.5.pli: ‘Abrahmacariyaṃ pahāya brahmacārī samaṇo gotamo ārācārī virato methunā gāmadhammā’ti—
dn1:1.8.5.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up unchastity. He is chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.’
dn1:1.8.5.comm: “Chastity” is brahmacariya, literally “divine conduct”. Here it is used in the narrow sense of refraining from sex, but more commonly it has a broader sense of “spiritual life”.

dn1:1.8.6.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.8.6.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.9.1.pli: ‘Musāvādaṃ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo saccavādī saccasandho theto paccayiko avisaṃvādako lokassā’ti—
dn1:1.9.1.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up lying. He speaks the truth and sticks to the truth. He’s honest and dependable, and doesn’t trick the world with his words.’
dn1:1.9.1.comm: This is the first of the four kinds of right speech. Just as the precept of not killing implies the positive injunction to live with compassion, the precepts on speech enjoin a positive and constructive use of speech.

dn1:1.9.2.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.9.2.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.9.3.pli: ‘Pisuṇaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo, ito sutvā na amutra akkhātā imesaṃ bhedāya, amutra vā sutvā na imesaṃ akkhātā amūsaṃ bhedāya. Iti bhinnānaṃ vā sandhātā, sahitānaṃ vā anuppadātā samaggārāmo samaggarato samagganandī samaggakaraṇiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā’ti—
dn1:1.9.3.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up divisive speech. He doesn’t repeat in one place what he heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, he reconciles those who are divided and support those who are united, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.’
dn1:1.9.3.comm: “Harmony” (or “unanimity”, samagga) does not excuse untrue, bigoted, or otherwise harmful speech. True harmony is only achieved in the presence of the Dhamma.

dn1:1.9.4.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.9.4.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.9.5.pli: ‘Pharusaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo, yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā’ti—
dn1:1.9.5.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up harsh speech. He speaks in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.’

dn1:1.9.6.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.9.6.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.9.7.pli: ‘Samphappalāpaṃ pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī, nidhānavatiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā kālena sāpadesaṃ pariyantavatiṃ atthasaṃhitan’ti—
dn1:1.9.7.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up talking nonsense. His words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. He says things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.’
dn1:1.9.7.comm: Attha is a polyvalent term, here taking the senses “meaningful” and “beneficial”. Elsewhere it means “goal”, “need”, “purpose”, “lawsuit”, or “ending”, and the senses are not always easy to untangle.

dn1:1.9.8.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.9.8.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.10.1.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama refrains from injuring plants and seeds.’
dn1:1.10.1.comm: Buddhists generally do not regard plants as sentient, but value them as part of the ecosystem that supports all life.

dn1:1.10.3.eng: ‘He eats in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.’
dn1:1.10.3.comm: From MN 66:6.4 and MN 70:4.8 we can see that “at night” means after dark, while “at the wrong time” means in the afternoon. More explicitly, these are the “wrong time at night” and the “wrong time in the day”, in which case they are both the “wrong time”.

dn1:1.10.4.eng: ‘He refrains from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music .’
dn1:1.10.4.comm: Such sensual entertainments distract and excite the mind. This and the next three precepts encourage peace of mind for meditation.

dn1:1.10.5.eng: ‘He refrains from attiring and adorning himself with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.’
dn1:1.10.5.comm: This was ignored by the Buddha’s cousin, Nanda (SN 21.8:1.2).

dn1:1.10.6.eng: ‘He refrains from high and luxurious beds.’

dn1:1.10.7.eng: ‘He refrains from receiving gold and currency,
dn1:1.10.7.comm: Literally “gold and silver” (jātarūparajata), but rajata is explained in Bu NP 18:2.8 as currency of any kind.

dn1:1.10.8.comm: Mendicants receive only the day’s meal and do not store or cook food.

dn1:1.10.11.comm: According to ancient Indian law (Arthaśāstra 3.13), a person in a time of trouble may bind themselves in service for a fee. Such bondservants were protected against cruelty, sexual abuse, and unfair work. After earning back the fee of their indenture they were freed, retaining their original inheritance and status.

dn1:1.10.12.comm: These are animals raised for food.

dn1:1.10.15.comm: Land for a monastery may be accepted by the Saṅgha as a community, but not by individual mendicants.

dn1:1.10.16.eng: ‘He refrains from running errands and messages;
dn1:1.10.16.comm: These items are discussed in detail below. | Acting as a go-between for lay business was tempting due to the mendicants’ wandering lifestyle. However, it exposes them to risk if the message is not delivered or if it is bad news.

dn1:1.10.17.comm: For example, trading in monastery property.

dn1:1.10.20.eng: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.’

dn1:1.10.21.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.10.21.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.10.22.eng: The shorter section on ethics is finished.

dn1:1.11.1.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhaṃ anuyuttā viharanti,
dn1:1.11.1.eng: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in injuring plants and seeds.
dn1:1.11.1.comm: This section expands some of the former section in further detail. | The “middle” and “large” sections on ethics are not found in briefer presentations such as MN 27:14.1.

dn1:1.11.2.pli: seyyathidaṃ—mūlabījaṃ khandhabījaṃ phaḷubījaṃ aggabījaṃ bījabījameva pañcamaṃ;
dn1:1.11.2.eng: These include plants propagated from roots, stems, cuttings, or joints; and those from regular seeds as the fifth.
dn1:1.11.2.comm: That these are not five “kinds of seeds” but five kinds of “plants grown from seeds” is clear from the Vinaya and its commentary (Bu Pc 11: Bhūtagāmo nāma pañca bījajātāni).

dn1:1.11.3.pli: iti evarūpā bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
dn1:1.11.3.eng: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such injury to plants and seeds.’

dn1:1.11.4.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.11.4.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.12.1.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ sannidhikāraparibhogaṃ anuyuttā viharanti,
dn1:1.12.1.eng: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in storing up goods for their own use.
dn1:1.12.1.comm: For storing up food as a sign of decline, see DN 27:17.5.

dn1:1.12.2.pli: seyyathidaṃ—annasannidhiṃ pānasannidhiṃ vatthasannidhiṃ yānasannidhiṃ sayanasannidhiṃ gandhasannidhiṃ āmisasannidhiṃ
dn1:1.12.2.eng: This includes such things as food, drink, clothes, vehicles, bedding, fragrance, and things of the flesh.

dn1:1.12.3.pli: iti vā iti evarūpā sannidhikāraparibhogā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
dn1:1.12.3.eng: The ascetic Gotama refrains from storing up such goods.’

dn1:1.12.4.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.12.4.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.13.1.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ visūkadassanaṃ anuyuttā viharanti,
dn1:1.13.1.eng: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in seeing shows.

dn1:1.13.2.pli: seyyathidaṃ—naccaṃ gītaṃ vāditaṃ pekkhaṃ akkhānaṃ pāṇissaraṃ vetāḷaṃ kumbhathūṇaṃ sobhanakaṃ caṇḍālaṃ vaṃsaṃ dhovanaṃ hatthiyuddhaṃ assayuddhaṃ mahiṃsayuddhaṃ usabhayuddhaṃ ajayuddhaṃ meṇḍayuddhaṃ kukkuṭayuddhaṃ vaṭṭakayuddhaṃ daṇḍayuddhaṃ muṭṭhiyuddhaṃ nibbuddhaṃ uyyodhikaṃ balaggaṃ senābyūhaṃ anīkadassanaṃ
dn1:1.13.2.eng: This includes such things as dancing, singing, music, performances, and storytelling; clapping, gongs, and kettledrums; beauty pageants; pole-acrobatics and bone-washing displays of the corpse-workers; battles of elephants, horses, buffaloes, bulls, goats, rams, chickens, and quails; staff-fights, boxing, and wrestling; combat, roll calls of the armed forces, battle-formations, and regimental reviews.
dn1:1.13.2.comm: Sobhanaka (“beauty pageant”) is explained by the commentary as the movement (or “sprinkling”) of dancers, or their beautification and painting. The PTS reading sobha-nagarakaṁ, supported by an unrelated reference to a gandhabba city of that name, is spurious. | Caṇḍālaṁ vaṁsaṁ dhovanaṁ should be a compound, as shown by the prose to Ja 498, where it is a performance by corpse-workers (caṇḍāla) in Ujjenī. Vaṁsa is the bamboo used by caṇḍāla acrobats (SN 47.19). Dhovana is referred by the commentary to AN 10.107, where it is a southern ceremony accompanied by drink and dance. The commentaries to AN and DN say it was the ritual washing of the bones of the buried dead after the decomposition of the flesh. Such “second funeral” rites have been observed world-wide. From the Jātaka it appears that the tradition had declined to a mere display for passers-by, perhaps featuring naked tribal girls. | Uyodhika is sometimes said to be “sham fights”, but at AN 10.30 it is not a sham. And the definition at Bu Pc 50 says “where strife is seen”.

dn1:1.13.3.pli: iti vā iti evarūpā visūkadassanā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
dn1:1.13.3.eng: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such shows.’

dn1:1.13.4.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.13.4.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.14.1.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ jūtappamādaṭṭhānānuyogaṃ anuyuttā viharanti,
dn1:1.14.1.eng: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in gambling that causes negligence.

dn1:1.14.2.pli: seyyathidaṃ—aṭṭhapadaṃ dasapadaṃ ākāsaṃ parihārapathaṃ santikaṃ khalikaṃ ghaṭikaṃ salākahatthaṃ akkhaṃ paṅgacīraṃ vaṅkakaṃ mokkhacikaṃ ciṅgulikaṃ pattāḷhakaṃ rathakaṃ dhanukaṃ akkharikaṃ manesikaṃ yathāvajjaṃ
dn1:1.14.2.eng: This includes such things as checkers with eight or ten rows, checkers in the air, hopscotch, spillikins, board-games, tip-cat, drawing straws, dice, leaf-flutes, toy plows, somersaults, pinwheels, toy measures, toy carts, toy bows, guessing words from syllables, guessing another’s thoughts, and imitating musical instruments.
dn1:1.14.2.comm: “Checkers” (aṭṭhapada) was presumably the ancestor of the Gupta period caturaṅga and hence modern chess. | Yathāvajja is explained in the commentary as “mimicking deformities”, but I cannot find support elsewhere in Pali or Sanskrit for vajja in this sense. More likely it refers to musical instruments (Sanskrit vādya).

dn1:1.14.3.pli: iti vā iti evarūpā jūtappamādaṭṭhānānuyogā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
dn1:1.14.3.eng: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such gambling.’

dn1:1.14.4.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.14.4.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.15.1.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ uccāsayanamahāsayanaṃ anuyuttā viharanti,
dn1:1.15.1.eng: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still make use of high and luxurious bedding.

dn1:1.15.2.pli: seyyathidaṃ—āsandiṃ pallaṅkaṃ gonakaṃ cittakaṃ paṭikaṃ paṭalikaṃ tūlikaṃ vikatikaṃ uddalomiṃ ekantalomiṃ kaṭṭissaṃ koseyyaṃ kuttakaṃ hatthattharaṃ assattharaṃ rathattharaṃ ajinappaveṇiṃ kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇaṃ sauttaracchadaṃ ubhatolohitakūpadhānaṃ
dn1:1.15.2.eng: This includes such things as sofas, couches, woolen covers—shag-piled, colorful, white, embroidered with flowers, quilted, embroidered with animals, double- or single-fringed—and silk covers studded with gems, as well as silken sheets, woven carpets, rugs for elephants, horses, or chariots, antelope hide rugs, and spreads of fine deer hide, with a canopy above and red cushions at both ends.

dn1:1.15.3.pli: iti vā iti evarūpā uccāsayanamahāsayanā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
dn1:1.15.3.eng: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such bedding.’

dn1:1.15.4.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.15.4.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.16.1.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ maṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānānuyogaṃ anuyuttā viharanti, seyyathidaṃ—
dn1:1.16.1.eng: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in attiring and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.

dn1:1.16.2.pli: ucchādanaṃ parimaddanaṃ nhāpanaṃ sambāhanaṃ ādāsaṃ añjanaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ mukhacuṇṇaṃ mukhalepanaṃ hatthabandhaṃ sikhābandhaṃ daṇḍaṃ nāḷikaṃ asiṃ chattaṃ citrupāhanaṃ uṇhīsaṃ maṇiṃ vālabījaniṃ odātāni vatthāni dīghadasāni
dn1:1.16.2.eng: This includes such things as applying beauty products by anointing, massaging, bathing, and rubbing; mirrors, ointments, garlands, fragrances, and makeup; face-powder, foundation, bracelets, headbands, fancy walking-sticks or containers, rapiers, parasols, fancy sandals, turbans, jewelry, chowries, and long-fringed white robes.

dn1:1.16.3.pli: iti vā iti evarūpā maṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānānuyogā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
dn1:1.16.3.eng: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such beautification and adornment.’

dn1:1.16.4.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.16.4.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.17.1.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ tiracchānakathaṃ anuyuttā viharanti,
dn1:1.17.1.eng: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in low talk. This includes such topics as
dn1:1.17.1.comm: Tiracchānakathā literally means “animal talk”. The Pali word for animal, tiracchāna has the sense of “moving horizontally”, and “low talk” is that which does not elevate.

dn1:1.17.2.pli: seyyathidaṃ—rājakathaṃ corakathaṃ mahāmattakathaṃ senākathaṃ bhayakathaṃ yuddhakathaṃ annakathaṃ pānakathaṃ vatthakathaṃ sayanakathaṃ mālākathaṃ gandhakathaṃ ñātikathaṃ yānakathaṃ gāmakathaṃ nigamakathaṃ nagarakathaṃ janapadakathaṃ itthikathaṃ sūrakathaṃ visikhākathaṃ kumbhaṭṭhānakathaṃ pubbapetakathaṃ nānattakathaṃ lokakkhāyikaṃ samuddakkhāyikaṃ itibhavābhavakathaṃ
dn1:1.17.2.eng: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that place.
dn1:1.17.2.comm: Bhavābhava does not mean “existence and non-existence” but is a distributive compound, “this or that state of existence”. Indian religious texts are full of discussions about different heavens and hells.

dn1:1.17.3.pli: iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānakathāya paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
dn1:1.17.3.eng: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such low talk.’

dn1:1.17.4.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.17.4.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.18.1.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ viggāhikakathaṃ anuyuttā viharanti,
dn1:1.18.1.eng: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in arguments.

dn1:1.18.2.pli: seyyathidaṃ—na tvaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānāsi, ahaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānāmi, kiṃ tvaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānissasi, micchā paṭipanno tvamasi, ahamasmi sammā paṭipanno, sahitaṃ me, asahitaṃ te, purevacanīyaṃ pacchā avaca, pacchāvacanīyaṃ pure avaca, adhiciṇṇaṃ te viparāvattaṃ, āropito te vādo, niggahito tvamasi, cara vādappamokkhāya, nibbeṭhehi vā sace pahosīti
dn1:1.18.2.eng: They say such things as: “You don’t understand this teaching and training. I understand this teaching and training. What, you understand this teaching and training? You’re practicing wrong. I’m practicing right. I stay on topic, you don’t. You said last what you should have said first. You said first what you should have said last. What you’ve thought so much about has been disproved. Your doctrine is refuted. Go on, save your doctrine! You’re trapped; get yourself out of this—if you can!”
dn1:1.18.2.comm: The folly of disputatiousness is a consistent theme in the suttas, but is a special focus of the Aṭṭhakavagga of the Suttanipāta.

dn1:1.18.3.pli: iti vā iti evarūpāya viggāhikakathāya paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
dn1:1.18.3.eng: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such argumentative talk.’

dn1:1.18.4.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.18.4.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.19.1.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ dūteyyapahiṇagamanānuyogaṃ anuyuttā viharanti,
dn1:1.19.1.eng: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in running errands and messages.

dn1:1.19.2.pli: seyyathidaṃ—raññaṃ, rājamahāmattānaṃ, khattiyānaṃ, brāhmaṇānaṃ, gahapatikānaṃ, kumārānaṃ “idha gaccha, amutrāgaccha, idaṃ hara, amutra idaṃ āharā”ti
dn1:1.19.2.eng: This includes running errands for rulers, ministers, aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or princes who say: “Go here, go there. Take this, bring that from there.”
dn1:1.19.2.comm: “Rulers” (raññaṁ, genitive plural) include hereditary kings as well as the elected joint leaders of republican states such as the Sakyans or Vajjis.

dn1:1.19.3.pli: iti vā iti evarūpā dūteyyapahiṇagamanānuyogā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
dn1:1.19.3.eng: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such errands.’

dn1:1.19.4.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.19.4.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.20.1.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te kuhakā ca honti, lapakā ca nemittikā ca nippesikā ca, lābhena lābhaṃ nijigīsitāro ca
dn1:1.20.1.eng: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in deceit, flattery, hinting, and belittling, and using material things to chase after other material things.
dn1:1.20.1.comm: Some renunciants like to butter up potential donors, or make ostentatious displays to prompt further donations. | “Using material possessions to chase after other material possessions” includes trading monastery property for profit.

dn1:1.20.2.pli: iti evarūpā kuhanalapanā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
dn1:1.20.2.eng: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such fawning and flattery.’

dn1:1.20.3.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.20.3.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.20.4.eng: The middle section on ethics is finished.

dn1:1.21.1.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti,
dn1:1.21.1.eng: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
dn1:1.21.1.comm: This section focuses on practices that are wrong livelihood for a mendicant, though not for lay people. The Vinaya explains “low lore” as whatever is non-Buddhist or useless (Bi Pc 49), while the commentary says it leads not to emancipation but to heaven. Most of the items in this and the following sections are detailed in later astrological texts such as Varāhamihira’s Bṛhatsaṁhitā. There are too many correspondences to cite, so I’ll only mention those that impact the translation.

dn1:1.21.2.pli: seyyathidaṃ—aṅgaṃ nimittaṃ uppātaṃ supinaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ mūsikacchinnaṃ aggihomaṃ dabbihomaṃ thusahomaṃ kaṇahomaṃ taṇḍulahomaṃ sappihomaṃ telahomaṃ mukhahomaṃ lohitahomaṃ aṅgavijjā vatthuvijjā khattavijjā sivavijjā bhūtavijjā bhūrivijjā ahivijjā visavijjā vicchikavijjā mūsikavijjā sakuṇavijjā vāyasavijjā pakkajjhānaṃ saraparittāṇaṃ migacakkaṃ
dn1:1.21.2.eng: This includes such fields as augury, omenology, divining portents, interpreting dreams, divining features of men and women, divining holes in cloth gnawed by mice, fire offerings, ladle offerings, offerings of husks, rice powder, rice, ghee, or oil; offerings from the mouth, blood sacrifices, limb-reading; geomancy for building sites, fields, and cemeteries; exorcisms, earth magic, snake charming, poisons; the lore of the scorpion, the rat, the bird, and the crow; prophesying life span, chanting for protection, and divining omens from wild animals.
dn1:1.21.2.comm: The list has both aṅga and aṅgavijjā, and it’s hard to disambiguate them; the commentary tries, unpersuasively. BS 50 has aṅgavidyā, which is various kinds of “limb-reading” (compare modern “palmistry”) but no equivalent to aṅga. Perhaps it is a misspelling of the less-familiar aṅka, “mark, sign”, hence “augury”. | “Portents” (uppāta are discussed at BS 45. | Lakkhaṇa is detailed at BS 67–69 as a thorough assessment of the features of men and women, including physical marks, character, voice, gait, and so on. | Read khattavijjā (“political science”) per variant as khettavijjā (“geomancy”). | Sara in saraparitta means “sound” not “arrow”; compare with sarabhañña “chanting”. | Migacakka is explained in the commentary, supported by Bṛhatsaṁhitā, as interpretation of the cries and behaviors of wild animals. Here the suffix -cakka refers to the field of study. See also Mil 5.3.7:6.1 sācakkaṁ migacakkaṁ antaracakkaṁ (“divining omens from dogs, wild animals, and the directions around”), terms which are also found at Bṛhatsaṁhitā 2.17.

dn1:1.21.3.pli: iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
dn1:1.21.3.eng: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.’

dn1:1.21.4.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.21.4.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.22.1.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti,
dn1:1.22.1.eng: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.

dn1:1.22.2.pli: seyyathidaṃ—maṇilakkhaṇaṃ vatthalakkhaṇaṃ daṇḍalakkhaṇaṃ satthalakkhaṇaṃ asilakkhaṇaṃ usulakkhaṇaṃ dhanulakkhaṇaṃ āvudhalakkhaṇaṃ itthilakkhaṇaṃ purisalakkhaṇaṃ kumāralakkhaṇaṃ kumārilakkhaṇaṃ dāsalakkhaṇaṃ dāsilakkhaṇaṃ hatthilakkhaṇaṃ assalakkhaṇaṃ mahiṃsalakkhaṇaṃ usabhalakkhaṇaṃ golakkhaṇaṃ ajalakkhaṇaṃ meṇḍalakkhaṇaṃ kukkuṭalakkhaṇaṃ vaṭṭakalakkhaṇaṃ godhālakkhaṇaṃ kaṇṇikālakkhaṇaṃ kacchapalakkhaṇaṃ migalakkhaṇaṃ
dn1:1.22.2.eng: This includes reading the marks of gems, cloth, clubs, swords, spears, arrows, bows, weapons, women, men, boys, girls, male and female bondservants, elephants, horses, buffaloes, bulls, cows, goats, rams, chickens, quails, monitor lizards, rabbits, tortoises, or deer.
dn1:1.22.2.comm: The commentary oddly has “earrings or house-gables” for kaṇṇika (“eared one”), but it must be “rabbit”, for which see sasakaṇṇikā at Ja 535:76.

dn1:1.22.3.pli: iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
dn1:1.22.3.eng: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.’

dn1:1.22.4.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.22.4.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.23.1.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti,
dn1:1.23.1.eng: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.

dn1:1.23.2.pli: seyyathidaṃ—raññaṃ niyyānaṃ bhavissati, raññaṃ aniyyānaṃ bhavissati, abbhantarānaṃ raññaṃ upayānaṃ bhavissati, bāhirānaṃ raññaṃ apayānaṃ bhavissati, bāhirānaṃ raññaṃ upayānaṃ bhavissati, abbhantarānaṃ raññaṃ apayānaṃ bhavissati, abbhantarānaṃ raññaṃ jayo bhavissati, bāhirānaṃ raññaṃ parājayo bhavissati, bāhirānaṃ raññaṃ jayo bhavissati, abbhantarānaṃ raññaṃ parājayo bhavissati, iti imassa jayo bhavissati, imassa parājayo bhavissati
dn1:1.23.2.eng: This includes making predictions that the king will march forth or march back; or that our king will attack and the enemy king will retreat, or vice versa; or that our king will triumph and the enemy king will be defeated, or vice versa; and so there will be victory for one and defeat for the other.

dn1:1.23.3.pli: iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
dn1:1.23.3.eng: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.’

dn1:1.23.4.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.23.4.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.24.1.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti,
dn1:1.24.1.eng: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.

dn1:1.24.2.pli: seyyathidaṃ—candaggāho bhavissati, sūriyaggāho bhavissati, nakkhattaggāho bhavissati, candimasūriyānaṃ pathagamanaṃ bhavissati, candimasūriyānaṃ uppathagamanaṃ bhavissati, nakkhattānaṃ pathagamanaṃ bhavissati, nakkhattānaṃ uppathagamanaṃ bhavissati, ukkāpāto bhavissati, disāḍāho bhavissati, bhūmicālo bhavissati, devadudrabhi bhavissati, candimasūriyanakkhattānaṃ uggamanaṃ ogamanaṃ saṅkilesaṃ vodānaṃ bhavissati, evaṃvipāko candaggāho bhavissati, evaṃvipāko sūriyaggāho bhavissati, evaṃvipāko nakkhattaggāho bhavissati, evaṃvipākaṃ candimasūriyānaṃ pathagamanaṃ bhavissati, evaṃvipākaṃ candimasūriyānaṃ uppathagamanaṃ bhavissati, evaṃvipākaṃ nakkhattānaṃ pathagamanaṃ bhavissati, evaṃvipākaṃ nakkhattānaṃ uppathagamanaṃ bhavissati, evaṃvipāko ukkāpāto bhavissati, evaṃvipāko disāḍāho bhavissati, evaṃvipāko bhūmicālo bhavissati, evaṃvipāko devadudrabhi bhavissati, evaṃvipākaṃ candimasūriyanakkhattānaṃ uggamanaṃ ogamanaṃ saṅkilesaṃ vodānaṃ bhavissati
dn1:1.24.2.eng: This includes making predictions that there will be an eclipse of the moon, or sun, or stars; that the sun, moon, and stars will be in conjunction or in opposition; that there will be a meteor shower, a fiery horizon, an earthquake, or thunder in the heavens; that there will be a rising, a setting, a darkening, a brightening of the moon, sun, and stars. And it also includes making predictions about the results of all such phenomena.
dn1:1.24.2.comm: Despite this, astrology is commonly practiced today among Buddhist mendicants. | (Up)pathagamana can hardly mean that the sun, moon, and stars will “go astray”. Rather, patha here has the sense of “range”, so it means “come within range”, which describes an astrological conjunction. | For “fiery sky” (disāḍāha), i.e. a glow on the horizon, as an omen, see diśāṁ dāhe at Manusmṛti 4.115 and digdāha in BS 31.

dn1:1.24.3.pli: iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
dn1:1.24.3.eng: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.’

dn1:1.24.4.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.24.4.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.25.1.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti,
dn1:1.25.1.eng: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.

dn1:1.25.2.pli: seyyathidaṃ—suvuṭṭhikā bhavissati, dubbuṭṭhikā bhavissati, subhikkhaṃ bhavissati, dubbhikkhaṃ bhavissati, khemaṃ bhavissati, bhayaṃ bhavissati, rogo bhavissati, ārogyaṃ bhavissati, muddā, gaṇanā, saṅkhānaṃ, kāveyyaṃ, lokāyataṃ
dn1:1.25.2.eng: This includes predicting whether there will be plenty of rain or drought; plenty to eat or famine; an abundant harvest or a bad harvest; security or peril; sickness or health. It also includes such occupations as arithmetic, accounting, calculating, poetry, and cosmology.
dn1:1.25.2.comm: “Cosmology” (lokāyata) in early Buddhist texts is not, as it later became known, the heterodox school of materialism. Rather, it was a branch of worldly knowledge within regular Vedic studies concerned with the nature and extent of the world and how this may be known (AN 9.38, SN 12.48; cf. Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 3.3.1).

dn1:1.25.3.pli: iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
dn1:1.25.3.eng: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.’

dn1:1.25.4.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.25.4.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.26.1.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti,
dn1:1.26.1.eng: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.

dn1:1.26.2.pli: seyyathidaṃ—āvāhanaṃ vivāhanaṃ saṃvaraṇaṃ vivaraṇaṃ saṅkiraṇaṃ vikiraṇaṃ subhagakaraṇaṃ dubbhagakaraṇaṃ viruddhagabbhakaraṇaṃ jivhānibandhanaṃ hanusaṃhananaṃ hatthābhijappanaṃ hanujappanaṃ kaṇṇajappanaṃ ādāsapañhaṃ kumārikapañhaṃ devapañhaṃ ādiccupaṭṭhānaṃ mahatupaṭṭhānaṃ abbhujjalanaṃ sirivhāyanaṃ
dn1:1.26.2.eng: This includes making arrangements for giving and taking in marriage; for engagement and divorce; and for scattering rice inwards or outwards at the wedding ceremony. It also includes casting spells for good or bad luck, treating impacted fetuses, binding the tongue, or locking the jaws; charms for the hands and ears; questioning a mirror, a girl, or a god as an oracle; worshiping the sun, worshiping the Great One, breathing fire, and invoking Siri, the goddess of luck.
dn1:1.26.2.comm: The commentary has saṅkiraṇa/vikiraṇa as “saving and spending” (cp. Snp 1.6:23.1), but it seems unlikely. Vikiraṇa means “scattering” food or sand, while Sanskrit vikira is the ritual scattering of rice. Given the context, I think it refers to the custom of scattering rice at a wedding. | For viruddhagabbhakaraṇa, viruddha means “obstructed”. The commentary here, in general agreement with the Niddesa on gabbhakaraṇa at Snp 4.14, explains as giving treatments for the survival of the fetus. | I omit hanujappana as it is absent from the commentary and seems to have just arisen by confusion.

dn1:1.26.3.pli: iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
dn1:1.26.3.eng: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.’

dn1:1.26.4.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.26.4.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.27.1.pli: ‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti,
dn1:1.27.1.eng: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.

dn1:1.27.2.pli: seyyathidaṃ—santikammaṃ paṇidhikammaṃ bhūtakammaṃ bhūrikammaṃ vassakammaṃ vossakammaṃ vatthukammaṃ vatthuparikammaṃ ācamanaṃ nhāpanaṃ juhanaṃ vamanaṃ virecanaṃ uddhaṃvirecanaṃ adhovirecanaṃ sīsavirecanaṃ kaṇṇatelaṃ nettatappanaṃ natthukammaṃ añjanaṃ paccañjanaṃ sālākiyaṃ sallakattiyaṃ dārakatikicchā mūlabhesajjānaṃ anuppadānaṃ osadhīnaṃ paṭimokkho
dn1:1.27.2.eng: This includes rites for propitiation, for granting wishes, for ghosts, for the earth, for rain, for property settlement, and for preparing and consecrating house sites, and rites involving sipping water and bathing, and oblations. It also includes administering emetics, purgatives, expectorants, and phlegmagogues; administering ear-oils, eye restoratives, nasal medicine, ointments, and counter-ointments; surgery with needle and scalpel, treating children, prescribing root medicines, and herbal bandages.
dn1:1.27.2.comm: Medicine is right livelihood, but a mendicant should not make a living from it. They may treat fellow mendicants, family members, or those close to the monastery. | Santikamma is the Sanskrit śāntikakarman, a rite for averting evil. | For vassakamma and vossakamma, the commentary has “fertile and infertile men” (vassoti puriso, vossoti paṇḍako), taking “rain” as a metaphor for semen. Such usages do have precedent elsewhere. But in context I take vassa simply as “rain” and vossa as equivalent to Sanskrit vyavasya in the sense of making a settlement for land. | I take paṭimokkho in the sense of “binding”; see pratimuñcate at Rig Veda 4.53.2, 5.81.2; paṭimokka at Ja 524:10, Ja 513:6; paṭimukka at MN 38:41.11 etc., rather than the commentary’s “release” (from the effects of caustic medicines; cf. Tha Ap 25:5.4).

dn1:1.27.3.pli: iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato samaṇo gotamo’ti—
dn1:1.27.3.eng: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.’

dn1:1.27.4.pli: iti vā hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.27.4.eng: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.27.5.pli: Idaṃ kho, bhikkhave, appamattakaṃ oramattakaṃ sīlamattakaṃ, yena puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya.
dn1:1.27.5.eng: These are the trivial, trifling details of mere ethics that an ordinary person speaks of when they speak praise of the Realized One.

dn1:1.27.6.eng: The longer section on ethics is finished.

dn1:1.28.1.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, aññeva dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
dn1:1.28.1.eng: There are other principles—deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute—which the Realized One makes known after realizing them with his own insight. Those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.
dn1:1.28.1.comm: One meaning of dhamma is “principle” in the sense of a natural law as well as a moral value. | Here begins the famous exposition of the sixty-two views. The subtlety of the analysis lies in how, rather than refuting the details of the views, the Buddha traces them all back to their fundamental psychology. | Pubbanta and aparanta (literally “prior end” and “posterior end) are technical terms found exclusively in Buddhism, and only used in the context of speculative views. It seems the Buddha had a contextual reason to avoid the generic words for “past” (atīta) and “future” (anāgata), and I reflect that in my translation. Pubbanta is semantically identical with pubbakoti, the “first point” of existence or transmigration (SN 48.50:5.3). This is emphasized by Nāgarjuna, who introduces the terms pubbanta and aparanta immediately after discussing the “first point” of transmigration, and associates them with the “extremes” (anta) of eternalism and annihilationism (Mūlamadhyamakakārikā 25.20–23). Thus such talk is not merely about the past as in what happened yesterday, or the future as in what I’ll do next week, but unmoored speculations about the “first beginning” and the “final end”.

dn1:1.28.2.pli: Katame ca te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ?

dn1:1.29.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā pubbantānudiṭṭhino, pubbantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi.
dn1:1.29.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the first beginning, and assert various hypotheses concerning the first beginning on eighteen grounds.
dn1:1.29.1.comm: “Hypothesis” is adhimuttipada, literally “statement of conviction”.

dn1:1.29.2.pli: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha pubbantakappikā pubbantānudiṭṭhino pubbantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi?
dn1:1.29.2.eng: And what are the eighteen grounds on which they rely?

dn1:1.30.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā, sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi.
dn1:1.30.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who are eternalists, who assert that the self and the cosmos are eternal on four grounds.
dn1:1.30.1.comm: In such contexts, the “self” (attā) is a postulated metaphysical entity rather than a simple psychological sense of personal identity. The nature of this “self” or “soul” was endlessly debated. The Buddha rejected all theories of a “self”, and elsewhere it is said that “identity view” underlies all sixty-two views of the Brahmajāla (SN 41.3:4.13). | The “cosmos” is the loka, otherwise translated as “world”. This sometimes refers to the simple physical realm, sometimes to the world of experience, or else, as here, the vast universe as conceived in ancient Indian thought.

dn1:1.30.2.pli: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi?
dn1:1.30.2.eng: And what are the four grounds on which they rely?

dn1:1.31.1.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte (…) anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
dn1:1.31.1.eng: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect their many kinds of past lives.
dn1:1.31.1.comm: “Immersion” (samādhi) is deep meditative stillness. The word conveys the sense of “gathered”, “collected”, with a secondary sense of “ignited”, “illuminated”. The practice of samādhi (or jhāna, “absorption”) has never been regarded as uniquely Buddhist. However, right meditation begins with right view. Since these meditators begin with wrong view, their samādhi is “wrong” because it merely reinforces their error. | These are those who rely on the “known” (viññāta) in the epistemic tetrad (MN 1:19.1).

dn1:1.31.2.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekānipi jātisatāni anekānipi jātisahassāni anekānipi jātisatasahassāni: ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
dn1:1.31.2.eng: That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
dn1:1.31.2.comm: The recollection of past lives is specific, detailed, and confident as it is based on the clear mind of deep immersion.

dn1:1.31.4.pli: ‘sassato attā ca loko ca vañjho kūṭaṭṭho esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito;
dn1:1.31.4.eng: ‘The self and the cosmos are eternal, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.
dn1:1.31.4.comm: This is the Upaniṣadic view of the eternal ātman that is the immanent soul of the world or cosmos, loka. Elsewhere in the suttas such theorists assert that the self and the cosmos are identical (SN 24.3:1.3: so attā so loko).

dn1:1.31.5.pli: te ca sattā sandhāvanti saṃsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthi tveva sassatisamaṃ.
dn1:1.31.5.eng: They remain the same for all eternity, while these sentient beings wander and transmigrate and pass away and rearise.
dn1:1.31.5.comm: The eternal “self” is contrasted with the ephemeral lives of beings. | The famous word saṁsara is often understood as a “cycle” of rebirths, but the meaning is, rather, to “wander on” or “transmigrate”. | For the phrase sassatisamaṁ (“lasting forever and ever”), compare Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 5.10.1: “He reaches that world free of sorrow and snow, where he lives forever and ever” (sa lokam āgacchaty aśokam ahimam | tasmin vasati śāśvatīḥ samāḥ).

dn1:1.31.7.pli: Ahañhi ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusāmi, yathāsamāhite citte anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi.
dn1:1.31.7.eng: Because by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind I experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that I recollect my many kinds of past lives,

dn1:1.31.8.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekānipi jātisatāni anekānipi jātisahassāni anekānipi jātisatasahassāni: “amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno”ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi.

dn1:1.31.9.comm: Their meditative experience revealed a process of transient and changing lives, yet from that they infer that there must be an eternal self.

dn1:1.31.10.pli: “yathā sassato attā ca loko ca vañjho kūṭaṭṭho esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito;
dn1:1.31.10.eng: “The self and the cosmos are eternal, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.

dn1:1.31.11.pli: te ca sattā sandhāvanti saṃsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthi tveva sassatisaman”’ti.
dn1:1.31.11.eng: They remain the same for all eternity, while these sentient beings wander and transmigrate and pass away and rearise.”’

dn1:1.31.12.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
dn1:1.31.12.eng: This is the first ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the self and the cosmos are eternal.

dn1:1.32.1.pli: Dutiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti?
dn1:1.32.1.eng: And what is the second ground on which they rely?

dn1:1.32.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
dn1:1.32.2.eng: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect their many kinds of past lives.

dn1:1.32.3.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—ekampi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭaṃ dvepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni tīṇipi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni cattāripi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni pañcapi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni dasapi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni: ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
dn1:1.32.3.eng: That is: one eon of the cosmos contracting and expanding; two, three, four, five, or ten eons of the cosmos contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
dn1:1.32.3.comm: This differs only in the length of time, which is now up to ten eons. A single eon (kappa) lasts longer than it would take to wear away a huge mountain by stroking it with a cloth once a century SN 15.5, while the number of eons is greater than the sands in the Ganges river SN 15.8. The vast time periods envisaged in early Buddhist texts are comparable with those of modern cosmology in physics.

dn1:1.32.5.pli: ‘sassato attā ca loko ca vañjho kūṭaṭṭho esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito;
dn1:1.32.5.eng: ‘The self and the cosmos are eternal, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.

dn1:1.32.6.pli: te ca sattā sandhāvanti saṃsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthi tveva sassatisamaṃ.
dn1:1.32.6.eng: They remain the same for all eternity, while these sentient beings wander and transmigrate and pass away and rearise.

dn1:1.32.8.pli: Ahañhi ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusāmi yathāsamāhite citte anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi.
dn1:1.32.8.eng: Because by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind I experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that I recollect my many kinds of past lives,

dn1:1.32.9.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—ekampi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭaṃ dvepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni tīṇipi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni cattāripi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni pañcapi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni dasapi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni: “amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno”ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi.

dn1:1.32.11.pli: “yathā sassato attā ca loko ca vañjho kūṭaṭṭho esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito, te ca sattā sandhāvanti saṃsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthi tveva sassatisaman”’ti.
dn1:1.32.11.eng: “The self and the cosmos are eternal, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar. They remain the same for all eternity, while these sentient beings wander and transmigrate and pass away and rearise.”’

dn1:1.32.12.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
dn1:1.32.12.eng: This is the second ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the self and the cosmos are eternal.

dn1:1.33.1.pli: Tatiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti?
dn1:1.33.1.eng: And what is the third ground on which they rely?

dn1:1.33.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
dn1:1.33.2.eng: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect their many kinds of past lives.

dn1:1.33.3.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—dasapi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni vīsampi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni tiṃsampi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni cattālīsampi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni: ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
dn1:1.33.3.eng: That is: ten eons of the cosmos contracting and expanding; twenty, thirty, or forty eons of the cosmos contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

dn1:1.33.5.pli: ‘sassato attā ca loko ca vañjho kūṭaṭṭho esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito;
dn1:1.33.5.eng: ‘The self and the cosmos are eternal, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.

dn1:1.33.6.pli: te ca sattā sandhāvanti saṃsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthi tveva sassatisamaṃ.
dn1:1.33.6.eng: They remain the same for all eternity, while these sentient beings wander and transmigrate and pass away and rearise.

dn1:1.33.8.pli: Ahañhi ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusāmi, yathāsamāhite citte anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi.
dn1:1.33.8.eng: Because by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind I experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that I recollect my many kinds of past lives,

dn1:1.33.9.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—dasapi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni vīsampi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni tiṃsampi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni cattālīsampi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni: “amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno”ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi.

dn1:1.33.11.pli: “yathā sassato attā ca loko ca vañjho kūṭaṭṭho esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito, te ca sattā sandhāvanti saṃsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthi tveva sassatisaman”’ti.
dn1:1.33.11.eng: “The self and the cosmos are eternal, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar. They remain the same for all eternity, while these sentient beings wander and transmigrate and pass away and rearise.”’

dn1:1.33.12.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
dn1:1.33.12.eng: This is the third ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the self and the cosmos are eternal.

dn1:1.34.1.pli: Catutthe ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti?
dn1:1.34.1.eng: And what is the fourth ground on which they rely?

dn1:1.34.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā takkī hoti vīmaṃsī, so takkapariyāhataṃ vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ sayaṃ paṭibhānaṃ evamāha:
dn1:1.34.2.eng: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin relies on logic and inquiry. They speak of what they have worked out by logic, following a line of inquiry, expressing their own perspective:
dn1:1.34.2.comm: These theorists used a process of logic (takka) and inquiry (vīmaṁsā), otherwise called “thought” (muta) in the epistemic tetrad (MN 1:19.1). They arrive at the same conclusion as the meditators. Different groups of ascetic philosophers emphasized contemplation or rational inquiry as the means to the truth. The Buddha acknowledged that both are useful but limited because, as here, they can sometimes lead to mistaken conclusions.

dn1:1.34.3.pli: ‘sassato attā ca loko ca vañjho kūṭaṭṭho esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito;
dn1:1.34.3.eng: ‘The self and the cosmos are eternal, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.

dn1:1.34.4.pli: te ca sattā sandhāvanti saṃsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthi tveva sassatisaman’ti.
dn1:1.34.4.eng: They remain the same for all eternity, while these sentient beings wander and transmigrate and pass away and rearise.’

dn1:1.34.5.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, catutthaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
dn1:1.34.5.eng: This is the fourth ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the self and the cosmos are eternal.

dn1:1.35.1.pli: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi.
dn1:1.35.1.eng: These are the four grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins assert that the self and the cosmos are eternal.

dn1:1.35.2.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva catūhi vatthūhi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena; natthi ito bahiddhā.
dn1:1.35.2.eng: Any ascetics and brahmins who assert that the self and the cosmos are eternal do so on one or other of these four grounds. Outside of this there is none.
dn1:1.35.2.comm: I have my doubts about this phrase. Everywhere else, ito bahiddhā means “outside of the Buddhist community”, not “outside of the cases just considered”. Still, the commentary and the Chinese parallel at T 21 agree on this sense.

dn1:1.36.2.pli: ‘ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānā evaṅgahitā evaṃparāmaṭṭhā evaṅgatikā bhavanti evaṃabhisamparāyā’ti,
dn1:1.36.2.eng: ‘If you hold on to and attach to these grounds for views it leads to such and such a destiny in the next life.’
dn1:1.36.2.comm: A “view” (diṭṭhi) is a relatively fixed framework for understanding the world; a “theory”. The “grounds for views” (diṭṭhiṭṭhānāni) are the bases from which the views are derived. In this case these are the meditative experiences or the logical reasoning.

dn1:1.36.3.pli: tañca tathāgato pajānāti, tato ca uttaritaraṃ pajānāti; tañca pajānanaṃ na parāmasati, aparāmasato cassa paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā.
dn1:1.36.3.eng: He understands this, and what goes beyond this. And since he does not misapprehend that understanding, he has realized quenching within himself.
dn1:1.36.3.comm: The word parāmasati means “to take hold” and is often used in the sense “to misapprehend”.

dn1:1.36.4.pli: Vedanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā anupādāvimutto, bhikkhave, tathāgato.
dn1:1.36.4.eng: Having truly understood the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape from feelings, the Realized One is freed through not grasping.
dn1:1.36.4.comm: Yathābhūtaṁ is often translated as “as it really is”, while I usually render it simply as “truly”. It often has a technical sense of seeing “how things came to be (bhuta)” as a process of conditionality (SN 12.31:7.1). Such direct vision of the truth is an attribute of the stream-enterer, who has realized the first of the four stages of awakening, in contrast with those on the path who still rely on faith or inference (SN 25.1). Here it refers to the understanding of feelings from a fivefold perspective. Feelings underlie intellectual theories and arguments, which serve to sate cravings and fears.

dn1:1.37.1.pli: Ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
dn1:1.37.1.eng: These are the principles—deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute—which the Realized One makes known after realizing them with his own insight. And those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.

dn1:1.37.2.comm: Long texts are sometimes marked by their “recitation sections” (bhāṇavāra), which was the length that would be recited in one session.

dn1:2.1.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi.
dn1:2.1.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who are partial eternalists, who assert that the self and the cosmos are partially eternal and partially not eternal on four grounds.
dn1:2.1.1.comm: Despite being views of the “self and the cosmos”, the main focus in the next four views is the self.

dn1:2.1.2.pli: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi?
dn1:2.1.2.eng: And what are the four grounds on which they rely?

dn1:2.2.1.pli: Hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo, yaṃ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena ayaṃ loko saṃvaṭṭati.
dn1:2.2.1.eng: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, this cosmos contracts.
dn1:2.2.1.comm: This is the end of an eon. It might be compared with what the physicists call the “big crunch”.

dn1:2.2.2.pli: Saṃvaṭṭamāne loke yebhuyyena sattā ābhassarasaṃvattanikā honti.
dn1:2.2.2.eng: As the cosmos contracts, sentient beings are mostly headed for the realm of streaming radiance.
dn1:2.2.2.comm: The human and similar realms are destroyed in the conflagration at the end of the universe, but sentient beings are sustained by the power of their past kamma. | The “realm of streaming radiance” is a Brahmā heaven corresponding to the second jhāna.

dn1:2.2.3.pli: Te tattha honti manomayā pītibhakkhā sayaṃpabhā antalikkhacarā subhaṭṭhāyino, ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭhanti.
dn1:2.2.3.eng: There they are mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, wandering in midair, steadily glorious, and they remain like that for a very long time.
dn1:2.2.3.comm: “Mind-made” (manomaya) beings are spontaneously born due to past kamma, not by sex. | “Rapture” (pīti) is a joyous emotional response to pleasure, usually a spiritual sense of elevation or uplift in meditation. | “Self-lumious” (sayaṁpabhā) as an external representation of the light of absorption through which they attained their exalted status. In the Rig Veda it is used of the divine light of the sun (1.52.9 svaścandram; 6.64.4 svabhāna) or the lightning (5.87.5 svarociṣa; 1.82.2 svabhāna).

dn1:2.3.1.pli: Hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo, yaṃ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena ayaṃ loko vivaṭṭati.
dn1:2.3.1.eng: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, this cosmos expands.
dn1:2.3.1.comm: This might be compared with the “big bang” of a cyclic universe.

dn1:2.3.2.eng: As it expands an empty mansion of divinity appears.
dn1:2.3.2.comm: The realms into which beings are reborn exist interdependently with the beings themselves. The different dimensions correspond with different kinds of kamma.

dn1:2.3.3.pli: Atha kho aññataro satto āyukkhayā vā puññakkhayā vā ābhassarakāyā cavitvā suññaṃ brahmavimānaṃ upapajjati.
dn1:2.3.3.eng: Then a certain sentient being—due to the running out of their lifespan or merit—passes away from that host of radiant deities and is reborn in that empty mansion of divinity.
dn1:2.3.3.comm: That is, they pass from a world corresponding to the second jhāna to one corresponding to the first jhāna.

dn1:2.3.4.pli: So tattha hoti manomayo pītibhakkho sayampabho antalikkhacaro subhaṭṭhāyī, ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭhati.
dn1:2.3.4.eng: There they are mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, wandering in midair, steadily glorious, and they remain like that for a very long time.

dn1:2.4.1.pli: Tassa tattha ekakassa dīgharattaṃ nivusitattā anabhirati paritassanā uppajjati:
dn1:2.4.1.eng: But after staying there all alone for a long time, they become dissatisfied and anxious:
dn1:2.4.1.comm: This passage echoes the creation myth in Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.4. At 1.4.2, the self-created Divinity feels fearful and alone, and at 1.4.3 and 1.4.17 wishes for a partner. From a Buddhist point of view, this simply shows how even God is trapped by emotional attachments in the cycle of transmigration.

dn1:2.4.2.eng: ‘Oh, if only other beings would come to this place.’

dn1:2.4.3.pli: Atha aññepi sattā āyukkhayā vā puññakkhayā vā ābhassarakāyā cavitvā brahmavimānaṃ upapajjanti tassa sattassa sahabyataṃ.
dn1:2.4.3.eng: Then other sentient beings—due to the running out of their lifespan or merit—pass away from that host of radiant deities and are reborn in that mansion of divinity in company with that being.
dn1:2.4.3.comm: These beings are reborn according to their own kamma, and it is just a coincidence that they appear after the first being made their wish.

dn1:2.4.4.pli: Tepi tattha honti manomayā pītibhakkhā sayaṃpabhā antalikkhacarā subhaṭṭhāyino, ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭhanti.
dn1:2.4.4.eng: There they too are mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, wandering in midair, steadily glorious, and they remain like that for a very long time.

dn1:2.5.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yo so satto paṭhamaṃ upapanno tassa evaṃ hoti:
dn1:2.5.1.eng: Now, the being who was reborn there first thinks:

dn1:2.5.2.pli: ‘ahamasmi brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṃ.
dn1:2.5.2.eng: ‘I am the Divinity, the Great Divinity, the Vanquisher, the Unvanquished, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, God Almighty, the Maker, the Creator, the First, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born.
dn1:2.5.2.comm: His first words ahamasmi brahmā (“I am Brahmā”) are equivalent to aham brahmāsmīti at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.4.10.

dn1:2.5.3.eng: These beings were created by me!
dn1:2.5.3.comm: At Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.4.5 the Divinity thinks, “I created all this”.

dn1:2.5.6.eng: “Oh, if only other beings would come to this place.”

dn1:2.5.7.pli: Iti mama ca manopaṇidhi, ime ca sattā itthattaṃ āgatā’ti.
dn1:2.5.7.eng: Such was my heart’s wish, and then these creatures came to this place.’
dn1:2.5.7.comm: The other creatures appeared after his wish, not because of it. God confuses correlation with causation, a mistake perpetuated by no small number of his followers.

dn1:2.5.8.pli: Yepi te sattā pacchā upapannā, tesampi evaṃ hoti:
dn1:2.5.8.eng: And the beings who were reborn there later also think:

dn1:2.5.9.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho bhavaṃ brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṃ.
dn1:2.5.9.eng: ‘This must be the Divinity, the Great Divinity, the Vanquisher, the Unvanquished, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, God Almighty, the Maker, the Creator, the First, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born.

dn1:2.5.10.eng: And we were created by him.

dn1:2.5.12.pli: Imañhi mayaṃ addasāma idha paṭhamaṃ upapannaṃ, mayaṃ panamha pacchā upapannā’ti.
dn1:2.5.12.eng: Because we see that he was reborn here first, and we arrived later.’
dn1:2.5.12.comm: At Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.4.9–10 the created humans also think first about the Divinity who preceded them, from whose knowledge of self all was created.

dn1:2.6.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yo so satto paṭhamaṃ upapanno, so dīghāyukataro ca hoti vaṇṇavantataro ca mahesakkhataro ca.
dn1:2.6.1.eng: And the being who was reborn first is more long-lived, beautiful, and illustrious than those who arrived later.

dn1:2.6.2.pli: Ye pana te sattā pacchā upapannā, te appāyukatarā ca honti dubbaṇṇatarā ca appesakkhatarā ca.

dn1:2.6.3.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, vijjati, yaṃ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṃ āgacchati.
dn1:2.6.3.eng: It’s possible that one of those beings passes away from that host and is reborn in this place.

dn1:2.6.4.pli: Itthattaṃ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
dn1:2.6.4.eng: Having done so, they go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

dn1:2.6.5.pli: Agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte taṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, tato paraṃ nānussarati.
dn1:2.6.5.eng: By dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind, they experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect that past life, but no further.
dn1:2.6.5.comm: Again, their meditation experience is genuine, but what they infer from it goes beyond the facts.
