dn1:2.6.7.pli: ‘yo kho so bhavaṃ brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṃ, yena mayaṃ bhotā brahmunā nimmitā, so nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo sassatisamaṃ tatheva ṭhassati.
dn1:2.6.7.eng: ‘He who is the Divinity—the Great Divinity, the Vanquisher, the Unvanquished, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, God Almighty, the Maker, the Creator, the First, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born—by he we were created. He is permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, remaining the same for all eternity.

dn1:2.6.8.pli: Ye pana mayaṃ ahumhā tena bhotā brahmunā nimmitā, te mayaṃ aniccā addhuvā appāyukā cavanadhammā itthattaṃ āgatā’ti.
dn1:2.6.8.eng: We who were created by that Divinity are impermanent, not lasting, short-lived, liable to pass away, and have come to this place.’
dn1:2.6.8.comm: The surviving forms of Indic religion (Buddhism, Hinduism, Jainism) typically hold that all creatures ultimately share the same nature and hence can find liberation. Here we see this was not always the case, for these theorists believed that there are inherently different orders of beings in the cosmos. This is not due to their conduct but to the circumstances of their creation.

dn1:2.6.9.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
dn1:2.6.9.eng: This is the first ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the self and the cosmos are partially eternal.

dn1:2.7.1.pli: Dutiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti?
dn1:2.7.1.eng: And what is the second ground on which they rely?

dn1:2.7.2.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, khiḍḍāpadosikā nāma devā, te ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannā viharanti. Tesaṃ ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannānaṃ viharataṃ sati sammussati. Satiyā sammosā te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti.
dn1:2.7.2.eng: There are gods named ‘depraved by play.’ They spend too much time laughing, playing, and making merry. And in doing so, they lose their mindfulness, and they pass away from that host of gods.
dn1:2.7.2.comm: Delightful as the life of the gods is, even they are supposed to retain a sense of moderation (MN 37:11.2), a lesson forgotten by those “depraved by play” (khiḍḍāpadosikā). | Note that mindfulness (sati) is not held to be a specifically Buddhist virtue. Here it refers to a sense of moral compass and self-awareness, rather than a meditation practice.

dn1:2.8.1.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, vijjati yaṃ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṃ āgacchati.
dn1:2.8.1.eng: It’s possible that one of those beings passes away from that host and is reborn in this place.

dn1:2.8.2.pli: Itthattaṃ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
dn1:2.8.2.eng: Having done so, they go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

dn1:2.8.3.pli: Agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte taṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, tato paraṃ nānussarati.
dn1:2.8.3.eng: By dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind, they experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect that past life, but no further.

dn1:2.9.2.pli: ‘ye kho te bhonto devā na khiḍḍāpadosikā, te na ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannā viharanti. Tesaṃ na ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannānaṃ viharataṃ sati na sammussati. Satiyā asammosā te devā tamhā kāyā na cavanti;
dn1:2.9.2.eng: ‘The gods not depraved by play don’t spend too much time laughing, playing, and making merry. So they don’t lose their mindfulness, and don’t pass away from that host of gods.

dn1:2.9.3.pli: niccā dhuvā sassatā avipariṇāmadhammā sassatisamaṃ tatheva ṭhassanti.
dn1:2.9.3.eng: They are permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, remaining the same for all eternity.

dn1:2.9.4.pli: Ye pana mayaṃ ahumhā khiḍḍāpadosikā, te mayaṃ ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannā viharimhā. Tesaṃ no ativelaṃ hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannānaṃ viharataṃ sati sammussati. Satiyā sammosā evaṃ mayaṃ tamhā kāyā cutā
dn1:2.9.4.eng: But we who were depraved by play spent too much time laughing, playing, and making merry. In doing so, we lost our mindfulness, and passed away from that host of gods.

dn1:2.9.5.pli: aniccā addhuvā appāyukā cavanadhammā itthattaṃ āgatā’ti.
dn1:2.9.5.eng: We are impermanent, not lasting, short-lived, liable to pass away, and have come to this place.’
dn1:2.9.5.comm: Here the difference in beings is attributed not to the circumstances of their creation but to their behavior.

dn1:2.9.6.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
dn1:2.9.6.eng: This is the second ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the self and the cosmos are partially eternal.

dn1:2.10.1.pli: Tatiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti?
dn1:2.10.1.eng: And what is the third ground on which they rely?

dn1:2.10.2.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, manopadosikā nāma devā, te ativelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyanti. Te ativelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyantā aññamaññamhi cittāni padūsenti. Te aññamaññaṃ paduṭṭhacittā kilantakāyā kilantacittā. Te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti.
dn1:2.10.2.eng: There are gods named ‘malevolent’. They spend too much time gazing at each other, so they grow angry with each other, and their bodies and minds get tired. They pass away from that host of gods.
dn1:2.10.2.comm: The parallel between manopadosika (“malevolent”) and khiddapadosika (“depraved by play”) suggests a rendering “depraved in mind” for manopadosika. However, elsewhere in the suttas manopadosa consistently means “malicious intent” (MN 56:13.15, MN 93:18.30, DN 26:20.3. Also see mano padūseyya at MN 21:20.1 and MN 28:9.6. Thus the contrast is between greed and hate. | Here, as usual, mano and citta are synonyms for “mind”.

dn1:2.11.1.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, vijjati yaṃ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṃ āgacchati.
dn1:2.11.1.eng: It’s possible that one of those beings passes away from that host and is reborn in this place.

dn1:2.11.2.pli: Itthattaṃ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
dn1:2.11.2.eng: Having done so, they go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

dn1:2.11.3.pli: Agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte taṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, tato paraṃ nānussarati.
dn1:2.11.3.eng: By dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind, they experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect that past life, but no further.

dn1:2.12.2.pli: ‘ye kho te bhonto devā na manopadosikā, te nātivelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyanti. Te nātivelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyantā aññamaññamhi cittāni nappadūsenti. Te aññamaññaṃ appaduṭṭhacittā akilantakāyā akilantacittā. Te devā tamhā kāyā na cavanti,
dn1:2.12.2.eng: ‘The gods who are not malevolent don’t spend too much time gazing at each other, so they don’t grow angry with each other, their bodies and minds don’t get tired, and they don’t pass away from that host of gods.

dn1:2.12.3.pli: niccā dhuvā sassatā avipariṇāmadhammā sassatisamaṃ tatheva ṭhassanti.
dn1:2.12.3.eng: They are permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, remaining the same for all eternity.

dn1:2.12.4.pli: Ye pana mayaṃ ahumhā manopadosikā, te mayaṃ ativelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyimhā. Te mayaṃ ativelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyantā aññamaññamhi cittāni padūsimhā, te mayaṃ aññamaññaṃ paduṭṭhacittā kilantakāyā kilantacittā. Evaṃ mayaṃ tamhā kāyā cutā
dn1:2.12.4.eng: But we who were malevolent spent too much time gazing at each other, we grew angry with each other, our bodies and minds got tired, and we passed away from that host of gods.

dn1:2.12.5.pli: aniccā addhuvā appāyukā cavanadhammā itthattaṃ āgatā’ti.
dn1:2.12.5.eng: We are impermanent, not lasting, short-lived, liable to pass away, and have come to this place.’

dn1:2.12.6.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
dn1:2.12.6.eng: This is the third ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the self and the cosmos are partially eternal.

dn1:2.13.1.pli: Catutthe ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti?
dn1:2.13.1.eng: And what is the fourth ground on which they rely?

dn1:2.13.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā takkī hoti vīmaṃsī. So takkapariyāhataṃ vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ sayampaṭibhānaṃ evamāha:
dn1:2.13.2.eng: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin relies on logic and inquiry. They speak of what they have worked out by logic, following a line of inquiry, expressing their own perspective:

dn1:2.13.3.pli: ‘yaṃ kho idaṃ vuccati cakkhuṃ itipi sotaṃ itipi ghānaṃ itipi jivhā itipi kāyo itipi, ayaṃ attā anicco addhuvo asassato vipariṇāmadhammo.
dn1:2.13.3.eng: ‘That which is called “the eye”, “the ear”, “the nose”, “the tongue”, and also “the body”: that self is impermanent, not lasting, transient, perishable.
dn1:2.13.3.comm: The Buddha critiqued this view at SN 12.61, arguing that the body is, in fact, longer lasting than the mind.

dn1:2.13.4.pli: Yañca kho idaṃ vuccati cittanti vā manoti vā viññāṇanti vā ayaṃ attā nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo sassatisamaṃ tatheva ṭhassatī’ti.
dn1:2.13.4.eng: That which is called “mind” or “sentience” or “consciousness”: that self is permanent, everlasting, eternal, imperishable, remaining the same for all eternity.’
dn1:2.13.4.comm: The terms “mind” (citta), “sentience” (mano), and “consciousness” (viññāṇa) are broadly synonymous and in many cases may be substituted for one another. Nonetheless, they each have a particular context in which they predominate. Citta is to be developed, in which respect it pertains to the fourth noble truth, the path. Mano, which I translate here as “sentience” for the sake of disambiguation, is often used in the active sense of the deeds done by the mind, pertaining to the second noble truth, the origin of suffering. Viññāṇa is the key factor in the experince of suffering, pertaining to the first noble truth.

dn1:2.13.5.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, catutthaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
dn1:2.13.5.eng: This is the fourth ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the self and the cosmos are partially eternal.

dn1:2.14.1.pli: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi.
dn1:2.14.1.eng: These are the four grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins assert that the self and the cosmos are partially eternal and partially not eternal.

dn1:2.14.2.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva catūhi vatthūhi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena; natthi ito bahiddhā.
dn1:2.14.2.eng: Any ascetics and brahmins who assert that the self and the cosmos are partially eternal and partially not eternal do so on one or other of these four grounds. Outside of this there is none.

dn1:2.15.2.pli: ‘ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānā evaṅgahitā evaṃparāmaṭṭhā evaṅgatikā bhavanti evaṃabhisamparāyā’ti.
dn1:2.15.2.eng: ‘If you hold on to and attach to these grounds for views it leads to such and such a destiny in the next life.’

dn1:2.15.3.pli: Tañca tathāgato pajānāti, tato ca uttaritaraṃ pajānāti, tañca pajānanaṃ na parāmasati, aparāmasato cassa paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā.
dn1:2.15.3.eng: He understands this, and what goes beyond this. And since he does not misapprehend that understanding, he has realized quenching within himself.

dn1:2.15.4.pli: Vedanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā anupādāvimutto, bhikkhave, tathāgato.
dn1:2.15.4.eng: Having truly understood the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape from feelings, the Realized One is freed through not grasping.

dn1:2.15.5.pli: Ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
dn1:2.15.5.eng: These are the principles—deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute—which the Realized One makes known after realizing them with his own insight. And those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.

dn1:2.16.0.eng: 3.1.3. The Cosmos is Finite or Infinite

dn1:2.16.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi.
dn1:2.16.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who theorize about size, and assert that the cosmos is finite or infinite on four grounds.
dn1:2.16.1.comm: Here we move from views that conceive of both the self and the cosmos together to those that focus only on the physical extent of the cosmos. It is not  clear why these are classified as “views of the past”.

dn1:2.16.2.pli: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi?
dn1:2.16.2.eng: And what are the four grounds on which they rely?

dn1:2.17.1.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati.
dn1:2.17.1.eng: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they meditate perceiving the cosmos as finite.
dn1:2.17.1.comm: Once again the view is inferred from meditation, showing that meditative experience was regarded by some as revealing genuine truths about the physical realm.

dn1:2.17.5.pli: Ahañhi ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusāmi, yathāsamāhite citte antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharāmi.
dn1:2.17.5.eng: Because by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind I experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that I meditate perceiving the cosmos as finite.
dn1:2.17.5.comm: The nature of their meditation is assumed to be the nature of the world itself.

dn1:2.17.8.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti.
dn1:2.17.8.eng: This is the first ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the cosmos is finite or infinite.

dn1:2.18.1.pli: Dutiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti?
dn1:2.18.1.eng: And what is the second ground on which they rely?

dn1:2.18.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte anantasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati.
dn1:2.18.2.eng: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they meditate perceiving the cosmos as infinite.
dn1:2.18.2.comm: In each of the two previous sets of four views, the views themselves were the same, only the means of knowing them differed. Here the views themselves differ. The differences take the form of a tetralemma: A, not-A, both A and not-A, neither A nor not-A. This pattern is commonly found in early Buddhism, as well as Indian thought more generally. The final two items are not meant to be obscure or mysterious, but to express genuine possibilities that cannot be captured by a simple duality.

dn1:2.18.5.eng: The ascetics and brahmins who say that

dn1:2.18.6.eng: the cosmos is finite are wrong.
dn1:2.18.6.comm: It is common today to say that one’s own experience is valid for oneself. Clearly that is not how these philosophers thought.

dn1:2.18.7.eng: The cosmos is infinite and unbounded.

dn1:2.18.9.pli: Ahañhi ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusāmi, yathāsamāhite citte anantasaññī lokasmiṃ viharāmi.
dn1:2.18.9.eng: Because by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind I experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that I meditate perceiving the cosmos as infinite.

dn1:2.18.12.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti.
dn1:2.18.12.eng: This is the second ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the cosmos is finite or infinite.

dn1:2.19.1.pli: Tatiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti?
dn1:2.19.1.eng: And what is the third ground on which they rely?

dn1:2.19.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte uddhamadho antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati, tiriyaṃ anantasaññī.
dn1:2.19.2.eng: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they meditate perceiving the cosmos as finite vertically but infinite horizontally.
dn1:2.19.2.comm: They perceive the universe as spread out like a disc. One might call it a “discworld”.

dn1:2.19.4.eng: ‘The cosmos is both finite and infinite.

dn1:2.19.5.eng: The ascetics and brahmins who say that

dn1:2.19.6.eng: the cosmos is finite are wrong,

dn1:2.19.7.eng: and so are those who say that

dn1:2.19.9.pli: Antavā ca ayaṃ loko ananto ca.
dn1:2.19.9.eng: The cosmos is both finite and infinite.

dn1:2.19.11.pli: Ahañhi ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusāmi, yathāsamāhite citte uddhamadho antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharāmi, tiriyaṃ anantasaññī.
dn1:2.19.11.eng: Because by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind I experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that I meditate perceiving the cosmos as finite vertically but infinite horizontally.

dn1:2.19.13.pli: “yathā antavā ca ayaṃ loko ananto cā”’ti.
dn1:2.19.13.eng: “The cosmos is both finite and infinite.”’

dn1:2.19.14.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti.
dn1:2.19.14.eng: This is the third ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the cosmos is finite or infinite.

dn1:2.20.1.pli: Catutthe ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti?
dn1:2.20.1.eng: And what is the fourth ground on which they rely?

dn1:2.20.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā takkī hoti vīmaṃsī. So takkapariyāhataṃ vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ sayampaṭibhānaṃ evamāha:
dn1:2.20.2.eng: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin relies on logic and inquiry. They speak of what they have worked out by logic, following a line of inquiry, expressing their own perspective:

dn1:2.20.3.eng: ‘The cosmos is neither finite nor infinite.
dn1:2.20.3.comm: The text doesn’t specify what this is, but it might include the view that the ideas “finite” and “infinite” are inadequate to describe the universe. Consider a universe expanding at the speed of light. At any point in time it is not infinite, but as it is impossible to reach its end it is not finite either.

dn1:2.20.4.eng: The ascetics and brahmins who say that

dn1:2.20.5.eng: the cosmos is finite are wrong,

dn1:2.20.6.eng: as are those who say that

dn1:2.20.8.eng: and also those who say that

dn1:2.20.9.pli: “antavā ca ayaṃ loko ananto cā”ti, tesampi musā.
dn1:2.20.9.eng: the cosmos is both finite and infinite.

dn1:2.20.10.eng: The cosmos is neither finite nor infinite.’

dn1:2.20.11.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, catutthaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti.
dn1:2.20.11.eng: This is the fourth ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the cosmos is finite or infinite.

dn1:2.21.1.pli: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi.
dn1:2.21.1.eng: These are the four grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins assert that the cosmos is finite or infinite.

dn1:2.21.2.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva catūhi vatthūhi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena; natthi ito bahiddhā.
dn1:2.21.2.eng: Any ascetics and brahmins who assert that the cosmos is finite or infinite do so on one or other of these four grounds. Outside of this there is none.

dn1:2.22.2.pli: ‘ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānā evaṅgahitā evaṃparāmaṭṭhā evaṅgatikā bhavanti evaṃabhisamparāyā’ti.
dn1:2.22.2.eng: ‘If you hold on to and attach to these grounds for views it leads to such and such a destiny in the next life.’

dn1:2.22.3.pli: Tañca tathāgato pajānāti, tato ca uttaritaraṃ pajānāti, tañca pajānanaṃ na parāmasati, aparāmasato cassa paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā.
dn1:2.22.3.eng: He understands this, and what goes beyond this. And since he does not misapprehend that understanding, he has realized quenching within himself.

dn1:2.22.4.pli: Vedanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā anupādāvimutto, bhikkhave, tathāgato.
dn1:2.22.4.eng: Having truly understood the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape from feelings, the Realized One is freed through not grasping.

dn1:2.22.5.pli: Ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
dn1:2.22.5.eng: These are the principles—deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute—which the Realized One makes known after realizing them with his own insight. And those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.

dn1:2.23.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā, tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ catūhi vatthūhi.
dn1:2.23.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who are endless flip-floppers. Whenever they’re asked a question, they resort to verbal flip-flops and endless flip-flops on four grounds.
dn1:2.23.1.comm: Vikkhepa is “ﬂip-flopping”. | Amarā is explained in the commentary as either “undying” or “eel-like”. However, amarā in the sense of “eel” is found only in the commentary to this term so is probably spurious. The feminine form amarā is attested in Sanskrit (eg. Manu 2.148). See also note to SN 4.1:5.2.

dn1:2.23.2.pli: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ catūhi vatthūhi?
dn1:2.23.2.eng: And what are the four grounds on which they rely?

dn1:2.24.1.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ‘idaṃ kusalan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti, ‘idaṃ akusalan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
dn1:2.24.1.eng: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin doesn’t truly understand what is skillful and what is unskillful.
dn1:2.24.1.comm: This is a basic requirement for any spiritual teacher.

dn1:2.24.3.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho “idaṃ kusalan”ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāmi, “idaṃ akusalan”ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāmi.
dn1:2.24.3.eng: ‘I don’t truly understand what is skillful and what is unskillful.

dn1:2.24.4.pli: Ahañce kho pana “idaṃ kusalan”ti yathābhūtaṃ appajānanto, “idaṃ akusalan”ti yathābhūtaṃ appajānanto, “idaṃ kusalan”ti vā byākareyyaṃ, “idaṃ akusalan”ti vā byākareyyaṃ, taṃ mamassa musā.
dn1:2.24.4.eng: If I were to declare that something was skillful or unskillful I might be wrong.

dn1:2.24.5.pli: Yaṃ mamassa musā, so mamassa vighāto.
dn1:2.24.5.eng: That would be stressful for me,

dn1:2.24.6.pli: Yo mamassa vighāto so mamassa antarāyo’ti.
dn1:2.24.6.eng: and that stress would be an obstacle.’

dn1:2.24.7.pli: Iti so musāvādabhayā musāvādaparijegucchā nevidaṃ kusalanti byākaroti, na panidaṃ akusalanti byākaroti, tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭho samāno vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjati amarāvikkhepaṃ:
dn1:2.24.7.eng: So from fear and disgust with false speech they avoid stating whether something is skillful or unskillful. Whenever they’re asked a question, they resort to verbal flip-flops and endless flip-flops:
dn1:2.24.7.comm: Despite their dullness, they have a genuine sense of conscience and wish to avoid breaking precepts.

dn1:2.24.8.pli: ‘evantipi me no; tathātipi me no; aññathātipi me no; notipi me no; no notipi me no’ti.
dn1:2.24.8.eng: ‘I don’t say it’s like this. I don’t say it’s like that. I don’t say it’s otherwise. I don’t say it’s not so. And I don’t deny it’s not so.’
dn1:2.24.8.comm: A wise teacher avoids making pronouncements about what they do not understand, but these teachers use this as a cover to hide the fact that they do not understand anything.

dn1:2.24.9.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ.
dn1:2.24.9.eng: This is the first ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely when resorting to verbal flip-flops and endless flip-flops.

dn1:2.25.1.pli: Dutiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ?
dn1:2.25.1.eng: And what is the second ground on which they rely?

dn1:2.25.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ‘idaṃ kusalan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti, ‘idaṃ akusalan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
dn1:2.25.2.eng: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin doesn’t truly understand what is skillful and what is unskillful.

dn1:2.25.4.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho “idaṃ kusalan”ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāmi, “idaṃ akusalan”ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāmi.
dn1:2.25.4.eng: ‘I don’t truly understand what is skillful and what is unskillful.

dn1:2.25.5.pli: Ahañce kho pana “idaṃ kusalan”ti yathābhūtaṃ appajānanto, “idaṃ akusalan”ti yathābhūtaṃ appajānanto, “idaṃ kusalan”ti vā byākareyyaṃ, “idaṃ akusalan”ti vā byākareyyaṃ, tattha me assa chando vā rāgo vā doso vā paṭigho vā.
dn1:2.25.5.eng: If I were to declare that something was skillful or unskillful I might feel desire or greed or hate or repulsion.
dn1:2.25.5.comm: Here too they show a certain sincerity to avoid giving rise to unwholesome qualities.

dn1:2.25.6.pli: Yattha me assa chando vā rāgo vā doso vā paṭigho vā, taṃ mamassa upādānaṃ.
dn1:2.25.6.eng: That would be grasping on my part.

dn1:2.25.7.pli: Yaṃ mamassa upādānaṃ, so mamassa vighāto.
dn1:2.25.7.eng: That would be stressful for me,

dn1:2.25.8.pli: Yo mamassa vighāto, so mamassa antarāyo’ti.
dn1:2.25.8.eng: and that stress would be an obstacle.’

dn1:2.25.9.pli: Iti so upādānabhayā upādānaparijegucchā nevidaṃ kusalanti byākaroti, na panidaṃ akusalanti byākaroti, tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭho samāno vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjati amarāvikkhepaṃ:
dn1:2.25.9.eng: So from fear and disgust with grasping they avoid stating whether something is skillful or unskillful. Whenever they’re asked a question, they resort to verbal flip-flops and endless flip-flops:

dn1:2.25.10.pli: ‘evantipi me no; tathātipi me no; aññathātipi me no; notipi me no; no notipi me no’ti.
dn1:2.25.10.eng: ‘I don’t say it’s like this. I don’t say it’s like that. I don’t say it’s otherwise. I don’t say it’s not so. And I don’t deny it’s not so.’

dn1:2.25.11.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ.
dn1:2.25.11.eng: This is the second ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely when resorting to verbal flip-flops and endless flip-flops.

dn1:2.26.1.pli: Tatiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ?
dn1:2.26.1.eng: And what is the third ground on which they rely?

dn1:2.26.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ‘idaṃ kusalan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti, ‘idaṃ akusalan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
dn1:2.26.2.eng: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin doesn’t truly understand what is skillful and what is unskillful.

dn1:2.26.4.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho “idaṃ kusalan”ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāmi, “idaṃ akusalan”ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāmi.
dn1:2.26.4.eng: ‘I don’t truly understand what is skillful and what is unskillful.

dn1:2.26.5.pli: Ahañce kho pana “idaṃ kusalan”ti yathābhūtaṃ appajānanto “idaṃ akusalan”ti yathābhūtaṃ appajānanto “idaṃ kusalan”ti vā byākareyyaṃ, “idaṃ akusalan”ti vā byākareyyaṃ;
dn1:2.26.5.eng: Suppose I were to declare that something was skillful or unskillful.

dn1:2.26.6.pli: santi hi kho samaṇabrāhmaṇā paṇḍitā nipuṇā kataparappavādā vālavedhirūpā, te bhindantā maññe caranti paññāgatena diṭṭhigatāni,
dn1:2.26.6.eng: There are clever ascetics and brahmins who are subtle, accomplished in the doctrines of others, hair-splitters. You’d think they live to demolish convictions with their intellect.
dn1:2.26.6.comm: They avoid making statements, not from a sense of conscience, but for fear of public shaming.

dn1:2.26.7.pli: te maṃ tattha samanuyuñjeyyuṃ samanugāheyyuṃ samanubhāseyyuṃ.
dn1:2.26.7.eng: They might pursue, press, and grill me about that.

dn1:2.26.8.pli: Ye maṃ tattha samanuyuñjeyyuṃ samanugāheyyuṃ samanubhāseyyuṃ, tesāhaṃ na sampāyeyyaṃ.
dn1:2.26.8.eng: I’d be stumped by such a grilling.

dn1:2.26.9.pli: Yesāhaṃ na sampāyeyyaṃ, so mamassa vighāto.
dn1:2.26.9.eng: That would be stressful for me,

dn1:2.26.10.pli: Yo mamassa vighāto, so mamassa antarāyo’ti.
dn1:2.26.10.eng: and that stress would be an obstacle.’

dn1:2.26.11.pli: Iti so anuyogabhayā anuyogaparijegucchā nevidaṃ kusalanti byākaroti, na panidaṃ akusalanti byākaroti, tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭho samāno vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjati amarāvikkhepaṃ:
dn1:2.26.11.eng: So from fear and disgust with examination they avoid stating whether something is skillful or unskillful. Whenever they’re asked a question, they resort to verbal flip-flops and endless flip-flops:

dn1:2.26.12.pli: ‘evantipi me no; tathātipi me no; aññathātipi me no; notipi me no; no notipi me no’ti.
dn1:2.26.12.eng: ‘I don’t say it’s like this. I don’t say it’s like that. I don’t say it’s otherwise. I don’t say it’s not so. And I don’t deny it’s not so.’

dn1:2.26.13.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ.
dn1:2.26.13.eng: This is the third ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely when resorting to verbal flip-flops and endless flip-flops.

dn1:2.27.1.pli: Catutthe ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ?
dn1:2.27.1.eng: And what is the fourth ground on which they rely?

dn1:2.27.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā mando hoti momūho.
dn1:2.27.2.eng: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin is dull and stupid.

dn1:2.27.3.pli: So mandattā momūhattā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭho samāno vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjati amarāvikkhepaṃ:
dn1:2.27.3.eng: Because of that, whenever they’re asked a question, they resort to verbal flip-flops and endless flip-flops:

dn1:2.27.4.pli: ‘atthi paro loko’ti iti ce maṃ pucchasi, ‘atthi paro loko’ti iti ce me assa, ‘atthi paro loko’ti iti te naṃ byākareyyaṃ,
dn1:2.27.4.eng: ‘Suppose you were to ask me whether there is another world. If I believed that to be the case, I would say so.
dn1:2.27.4.comm: Here begins a series of four tetrads that are commonly encountered in the suttas. The first is the belief in an afterlife.

dn1:2.27.5.pli: ‘evantipi me no, tathātipi me no, aññathātipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me no’ti.
dn1:2.27.5.eng: But I don’t say it’s like this. I don’t say it’s like that. I don’t say it’s otherwise. I don’t say it’s not so. And I don’t deny it’s not so.

dn1:2.27.6.eng: Suppose you were to ask me whether there is no other world …

dn1:2.27.7.eng: whether there both is and is not another world …
dn1:2.27.7.comm: This could include a belief that eternal life is offered only to adherents of a certain religion.

dn1:2.27.8.eng: whether there neither is nor is not another world …
dn1:2.27.8.comm: This could include the idea that our intrinsic nature is one with the cosmos, and our separation from that infinitude in this life is only a veil of delusion. Thus there is no other world, because all worlds are this world, but it is also not the case that there is nothing after death.

dn1:2.27.9.eng: whether there are beings who are reborn spontaneously …
dn1:2.27.9.comm: This is beings such as the gods or various ghosts and spirits, which are not born organically.

dn1:2.27.10.eng: whether there are not beings who are reborn spontaneously …
dn1:2.27.10.comm: This denies the existence of such beings. Not everyone in ancient India believed in the various orders of beings.

dn1:2.27.11.eng: whether there both are and are not beings who are reborn spontaneously …
dn1:2.27.11.comm: The belief that beings are both spontaneously born and organically born. Perhaps this denies that such a distinction can be made clearly, because both kinds of birth take place within the same order of beings.

dn1:2.27.12.eng: whether there neither are nor are not beings who are reborn spontaneously …
dn1:2.27.12.comm: Beings are reborn in other ways.

dn1:2.27.13.eng: whether there is fruit and result of good and bad deeds …
dn1:2.27.13.comm: This is the standard Buddhist view of kamma, shared with some, but not all, of the other Indian religions of the time.

dn1:2.27.14.eng: whether there is no fruit and result of good and bad deeds …
dn1:2.27.14.comm: Doing good or bad has no result; moral nihilism.

dn1:2.27.15.pli: ‘atthi ca natthi ca sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko …pe…
dn1:2.27.15.eng: whether there both is and is not fruit and result of good and bad deeds …
dn1:2.27.15.comm: Sometimes good and bad deeds have results, other times not.

dn1:2.27.16.pli: ‘nevatthi na natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko …pe…
dn1:2.27.16.eng: whether there neither is nor is not fruit and result of good and bad deeds …
dn1:2.27.16.comm: The results of actions are too subtle to be described as good or bad.

dn1:2.27.17.eng: whether a realized one still exists after death …
dn1:2.27.17.comm: An awakened one, whether the Buddha or anyone else, exists after death, for example in an eternal state of Nirvana.

dn1:2.27.18.eng: whether a realized one no longer exists after death …
dn1:2.27.18.comm: A sage ceases to exist at the time of death. This assumes there is an enduring “self” that is done away with.

dn1:2.27.19.pli: ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā …pe…
dn1:2.27.19.eng: whether a realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death …
dn1:2.27.19.comm: For example, their body does not exist but their mind does.

dn1:2.27.20.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti iti ce maṃ pucchasi, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti iti ce me assa, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti iti te naṃ byākareyyaṃ,
dn1:2.27.20.eng: whether a realized one neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death. If I believed that to be the case, I would say so.
dn1:2.27.20.comm: A sage persists in a subtle state that cannot be characterized in terms of existence or non-existence.

dn1:2.27.21.pli: ‘evantipi me no, tathātipi me no, aññathātipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me no’ti.
dn1:2.27.21.eng: But I don’t say it’s like this. I don’t say it’s like that. I don’t say it’s otherwise. I don’t say it’s not so. And I don’t deny it’s not so.’

dn1:2.27.22.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, catutthaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ.
dn1:2.27.22.eng: This is the fourth ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely when resorting to verbal flip-flops and endless flip-flops.

dn1:2.28.1.pli: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ catūhi vatthūhi.
dn1:2.28.1.eng: These are the four grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins who are flip-floppers resort to verbal flip-flops and endless flip-flops whenever they’re asked a question.

dn1:2.28.2.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ, sabbe te imeheva catūhi vatthūhi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena, natthi ito bahiddhā …
dn1:2.28.2.eng: Any ascetics and brahmins who resort to verbal flip-flops and endless flip-flops do so on one or other of these four grounds. Outside of this there is none.

dn1:2.29.2.pli: yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
dn1:2.29.2.eng: And those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.

dn1:2.30.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi.
dn1:2.30.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who theorize about anomalous origination. They assert that the self and the cosmos arose anomalously on two grounds.
dn1:2.30.1.comm: Adhicca is usually translated in this context as “chance”. The root meaning refers to something that has been “lifted out”, making it a “special exception” or “anomaly”. It isn’t used in Sanskrit for a philosophical theory of chance, for which we find instead yadṛcchā (“arbitrariness”, Śvetāśvatara Upaniṣad 1.2). The theory proposed here is not that the universe in general operates by chance, but that the happenstance of creation is an “anomaly” in the general scheme of things. At SN 12.24:3.4 and SN 12.25:2.4 we learn that some philosophers who believed in the doctrine of kamma nonetheless argued that suffering arose anomalously.

dn1:2.30.2.pli: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi?
dn1:2.30.2.eng: And what are the two grounds on which they rely?

dn1:2.31.1.comm: This is an obscure realm of existence where the operations of consciousness are suspended.

dn1:2.31.2.pli: Saññuppādā ca pana te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti.
dn1:2.31.2.eng: When perception arises they pass away from that host of gods.

dn1:2.31.3.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, vijjati, yaṃ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṃ āgacchati.
dn1:2.31.3.eng: It’s possible that one of those beings passes away from that host and is reborn in this place.

dn1:2.31.4.pli: Itthattaṃ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
dn1:2.31.4.eng: Having done so, they go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

dn1:2.31.5.pli: Agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte saññuppādaṃ anussarati, tato paraṃ nānussarati.
dn1:2.31.5.eng: By dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind, they experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect the arising of perception, but no further.

dn1:2.31.7.eng: ‘The self and the cosmos arose anomalously.

dn1:2.31.9.pli: Ahañhi pubbe nāhosiṃ, somhi etarahi ahutvā santatāya pariṇato’ti.
dn1:2.31.9.eng: Because formerly I didn’t exist, whereas now, having not existed, I’ve transformed into the state of existing.”
dn1:2.31.9.comm: The idea of creation from nothingness is discussed at Rig Veda 10.129, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.2.

dn1:2.31.10.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
dn1:2.31.10.eng: This is the first ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the self and the cosmos arose anomalously.

dn1:2.32.1.pli: Dutiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti?
dn1:2.32.1.eng: And what is the second ground on which they rely?

dn1:2.32.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā takkī hoti vīmaṃsī.
dn1:2.32.2.eng: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin relies on logic and inquiry.

dn1:2.32.3.eng: They speak of what they have worked out by logic, following a line of inquiry, expressing their own perspective:

dn1:2.32.4.eng: ‘The self and the cosmos arose anomalously.’

dn1:2.32.5.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
dn1:2.32.5.eng: This is the second ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the self and the cosmos arose anomalously.

dn1:2.33.1.pli: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi.
dn1:2.33.1.eng: These are the two grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins who theorize about anomalous origination assert that the self and the cosmos arose anomalously.

dn1:2.33.2.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva dvīhi vatthūhi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena, natthi ito bahiddhā …
dn1:2.33.2.eng: Any ascetics and brahmins who theorize about anomalous origination do so on one or other of these two grounds. Outside of this there is none.

dn1:2.34.2.pli: yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
dn1:2.34.2.eng: And those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.

dn1:2.35.1.pli: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā pubbantānudiṭṭhino pubbantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi.
dn1:2.35.1.eng: These are the eighteen grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the first beginning assert various hypotheses concerning the first beginning.
dn1:2.35.1.comm: First each section is concluded, then the whole first part is concluded. This formalism is a characteristic of oral tradition. It creates a nested hierarchy of content, clarifying the structure and helping to preserve the text in memory.

dn1:2.35.2.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā pubbantakappikā pubbantānudiṭṭhino pubbantamārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena, natthi ito bahiddhā.
dn1:2.35.2.eng: Any ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the first beginning do so on one or other of these eighteen grounds. Outside of this there is none.

dn1:2.36.2.pli: ‘ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānā evaṅgahitā evaṃparāmaṭṭhā evaṅgatikā bhavanti evaṃabhisamparāyā’ti.
dn1:2.36.2.eng: ‘If you hold on to and attach to these grounds for views it leads to such and such a destiny in the next life.’

dn1:2.36.3.pli: Tañca tathāgato pajānāti, tato ca uttaritaraṃ pajānāti, tañca pajānanaṃ na parāmasati, aparāmasato cassa paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā.
dn1:2.36.3.eng: He understands this, and what goes beyond this. And since he does not misapprehend that understanding, he has realized quenching within himself.

dn1:2.36.4.pli: Vedanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā anupādāvimutto, bhikkhave, tathāgato.
dn1:2.36.4.eng: Having truly understood the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape from feelings, the Realized One is freed through not grasping.

dn1:2.36.5.pli: Ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
dn1:2.36.5.eng: These are the principles—deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute—which the Realized One makes known after realizing them with his own insight. And those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.

dn1:2.37.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparantakappikā aparantānudiṭṭhino, aparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi.
dn1:2.37.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the final end, and assert various hypotheses concerning the final end on forty-four grounds.
dn1:2.37.1.comm: This section introduces more tetralemmas. Many of the views describe the self in terms of the five aggregates—form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

dn1:2.37.2.pli: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha aparantakappikā aparantānudiṭṭhino aparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi?
dn1:2.37.2.eng: And what are the forty-four grounds on which they rely?

dn1:2.38.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ saññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti soḷasahi vatthūhi.
dn1:2.38.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who say there is life after death, and assert that the self lives on after death in a percipient form on sixteen grounds.
dn1:2.38.1.comm: “Percipient beings” are mentioned in the Jain Tattvārthasūtra 2.24.

dn1:2.38.2.pli: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ saññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti soḷasahi vatthūhi?
dn1:2.38.2.eng: And what are the sixteen grounds on which they rely?

dn1:2.38.3.pli: ‘Rūpī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā saññī’ti naṃ paññapenti.
dn1:2.38.3.eng: They assert: ‘The self is healthy and percipient after death, and it is formed …
dn1:2.38.3.comm: Usually a self is conceived of as percipient, so that the subject experiences a continuity. | The term aroga (“free of disease”) is explained by the commentary as “permanent” (nicca), drawing on the root sense of the word, “unbroken”. However, aroga is always used in the sense “free of disease, well, healthy” (eg. MN 97:2.4), and this applies to the Brahmanical tradition as well as the Buddhist. Chandogya Upaniṣad 7.26.2 says that one who sees (the self) does not see death, they have no disease or pain. Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.4.12 similarly says that one who sees the self will not suffer in the wake of the body, which Śaṅkāra explains, “Struggling with desires for himself, for his son, for his wife, and so on, he is born and dies again and again, and is diseased when his body is diseased.”

dn1:2.38.4.pli: ‘Arūpī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā saññī’ti naṃ paññapenti.

dn1:2.38.18.pli: ‘Adukkhamasukhī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā saññī’ti naṃ paññapenti.

dn1:2.39.1.pli: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ saññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti soḷasahi vatthūhi.
dn1:2.39.1.eng: These are the sixteen grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins assert that the self lives on after death in a percipient form.

dn1:2.39.2.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ saññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva soḷasahi vatthūhi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena, natthi ito bahiddhā …
dn1:2.39.2.eng: Any ascetics and brahmins who assert that the self lives on after death in a percipient form do so on one or other of these sixteen grounds. Outside of this there is none.

dn1:2.40.2.pli: yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
dn1:2.40.2.eng: And those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.

dn1:3.1.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ asaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi.
dn1:3.1.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who say there is life after death, and assert that the self lives on after death in a non-percipient form on eight grounds.

dn1:3.1.2.pli: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ asaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi?
dn1:3.1.2.eng: And what are the eight grounds on which they rely?

dn1:3.2.1.pli: ‘Rūpī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā asaññī’ti naṃ paññapenti.
dn1:3.2.1.eng: They assert: ‘The self is healthy and non-percipient after death, and it is formed …
dn1:3.2.1.comm: Here the self has a physical dimension but no perception. This might include rebirth as a plant or inanimate object.

dn1:3.2.2.pli: ‘Arūpī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā asaññī’ti naṃ paññapenti.

dn1:3.2.8.pli: ‘Nevantavā nānantavā attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā asaññī’ti naṃ paññapenti.

dn1:3.3.1.pli: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ asaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi.
dn1:3.3.1.eng: These are the eight grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins assert that the self lives on after death in a non-percipient form.

dn1:3.3.2.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ asaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva aṭṭhahi vatthūhi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena, natthi ito bahiddhā …
dn1:3.3.2.eng: Any ascetics and brahmins who assert that the self lives on after death in a non-percipient form do so on one or other of these eight grounds. Outside of this there is none.

dn1:3.4.2.pli: yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
dn1:3.4.2.eng: And those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.

dn1:3.5.0.eng: 3.2.3. Neither Percipient Nor Non-Percipient Life After Death

dn1:3.5.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā, uddhamāghātanaṃ nevasaññīnāsaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi.
dn1:3.5.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who say there is life after death, and assert that the self lives on after death in a neither percipient nor non-percipient form on eight grounds.
dn1:3.5.1.comm: Buddhism acknowledges a formless realm of neither perception nor non-perception, which is attained through advanced meditation.

dn1:3.5.2.pli: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ nevasaññīnāsaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi?
dn1:3.5.2.eng: And what are the eight grounds on which they rely?

dn1:3.6.1.pli: ‘Rūpī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā nevasaññīnāsaññī’ti naṃ paññapenti.
dn1:3.6.1.eng: They assert: ‘The self is healthy and neither percipient nor non-percipient after death, and it is formed …

dn1:3.6.8.pli: ‘Nevantavā nānantavā attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā nevasaññīnāsaññī’ti naṃ paññapenti.

dn1:3.7.1.pli: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ nevasaññīnāsaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi.
dn1:3.7.1.eng: These are the eight grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins assert that the self lives on after death in a neither percipient nor non-percipient form.

dn1:3.7.2.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ nevasaññīnāsaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva aṭṭhahi vatthūhi …
dn1:3.7.2.eng: Any ascetics and brahmins who assert that the self lives on after death in a neither percipient nor non-percipient form do so on one or other of these eight grounds. Outside of this there is none.

dn1:3.8.2.pli: yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
dn1:3.8.2.eng: And those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.

dn1:3.9.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ucchedavādā sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi.
dn1:3.9.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who are annihilationists. They assert the annihilation, eradication, and nonexistence of an existing being on seven grounds.
dn1:3.9.1.comm: These theorists assert the true existence of a being, thus falling into the fallacy of identity view. For the Buddha, the words “being” or a “self” describe an ongoing process that is conditioned and impermanent, and do not correspond to a genuine metaphysical reality. The distinction between contingent, empirical reality and metaphysical, absolute existence is essential to understanding early Buddhism.

dn1:3.9.2.pli: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha ucchedavādā sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi?
dn1:3.9.2.eng: And what are the seven grounds on which they rely?

dn1:3.10.1.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā evaṃvādī hoti evaṃdiṭṭhi:
dn1:3.10.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

dn1:3.10.2.pli: ‘yato kho, bho, ayaṃ attā rūpī cātumahābhūtiko mātāpettikasambhavo kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā sammā samucchinno hotī’ti.
dn1:3.10.2.eng: ‘This self is formed, made up of the four principal states, and produced by mother and father. Since it’s annihilated and destroyed when the body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death, that’s how this self becomes rightly annihilated.’
dn1:3.10.2.comm: This is the materialist view, which accepts only the coarse physical realm. This view is common today, but was also well known in the Buddha’s time. | The “four principal states” are earth, water, fire, and air, i.e. the states of matter: solid, liquid, plasma, and gas.

dn1:3.10.3.pli: Ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti.
dn1:3.10.3.eng: That is how some assert the annihilation of an existing being.

dn1:3.11.1.eng: But someone else says to them:

dn1:3.11.2.pli: ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi;
dn1:3.11.2.eng: ‘That self of which you speak does exist, I don’t deny it.
dn1:3.11.2.comm: The theorist accepts multiple selves. As self theories evolve, they typically move from more coarse materialist theories towards more subtle conceptions. Sometimes the former view is rejected as being false. Sometimes, as here, the former view is seen not as false, but as incomplete and shallow.

dn1:3.11.3.pli: no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā sammā samucchinno hoti.
dn1:3.11.3.eng: But that’s not how this self becomes rightly annihilated.

dn1:3.11.4.pli: Atthi kho, bho, añño attā dibbo rūpī kāmāvacaro kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkho.
dn1:3.11.4.eng: There is another self that is heavenly, formed, sensual, consuming edible food.
dn1:3.11.4.comm: “Form” (rūpa) includes not just the physical realm of the elements, but various kinds of subtle form (sukhumarūpa). These include the energetic or mind-made bodies of beings in various dimensions. Rūpa ultimately refers to the appearance or manifestation of physical properties, and can even include the perception of colors, lights, and shapes in the mind. Here the bodies of the divine beings are not very distant from our own, as they still consume solid food. This probably refers to various nature deities or entities that were believed to consume the food offered to them by humans.

dn1:3.11.5.pli: Taṃ tvaṃ na jānāsi na passasi.
dn1:3.11.5.eng: You don’t know or see that.

dn1:3.11.6.eng: But I know it and see it.

dn1:3.11.7.pli: So kho, bho, attā yato kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā sammā samucchinno hotī’ti.
dn1:3.11.7.eng: Since this self is annihilated and destroyed when the body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death, that’s how this self becomes rightly annihilated.’
dn1:3.11.7.comm: Whereas the eternalists believe that their heavenly rebirth will last forever, annihilationists believe that even heaven is limited, and it ends in final annihilation.

dn1:3.11.8.pli: Ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti.
dn1:3.11.8.eng: That is how some assert the annihilation of an existing being.

dn1:3.12.1.eng: But someone else says to them:

dn1:3.12.2.pli: ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi;
dn1:3.12.2.eng: ‘That self of which you speak does exist, I don’t deny it.

dn1:3.12.3.pli: no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā sammā samucchinno hoti.
dn1:3.12.3.eng: But that’s not how this self becomes rightly annihilated.

dn1:3.12.4.pli: Atthi kho, bho, añño attā dibbo rūpī manomayo sabbaṅgapaccaṅgī ahīnindriyo.
dn1:3.12.4.eng: There is another self that is heavenly, formed, mind-made, whole in its major and minor limbs, not deficient in any faculty.
dn1:3.12.4.comm: This is a more subtle kind of divine rebirth, no longer dependent on physical food. The subtle body still takes on a humanoid form, however, appearing complete in all its limbs. It includes realms produced through the practice of the four jhānas. | Sabbaṅga has the sense “whole and healthy of limb” (Rig Veda 10.161.5c, Atharva Veda 8.2.8c, 11.3.32 ff.). One is reborn with “whole body” (sarvatanu, Atharva Veda 5.6.11c, Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 11.1.8.60, 12.8.3.31). | Paccaṅga means “minor limb”, for example the fingers or internal organs.

dn1:3.12.5.pli: Taṃ tvaṃ na jānāsi na passasi.
dn1:3.12.5.eng: You don’t know or see that.

dn1:3.12.6.eng: But I know it and see it.

dn1:3.12.7.pli: So kho, bho, attā yato kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā sammā samucchinno hotī’ti.
dn1:3.12.7.eng: Since this self is annihilated and destroyed when the body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death, that’s how this self becomes rightly annihilated.’

dn1:3.12.8.pli: Ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti.
dn1:3.12.8.eng: That is how some assert the annihilation of an existing being.

dn1:3.13.1.eng: But someone else says to them:

dn1:3.13.2.pli: ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi;
dn1:3.13.2.eng: ‘That self of which you speak does exist, I don’t deny it.

dn1:3.13.3.pli: no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā sammā samucchinno hoti.
dn1:3.13.3.eng: But that’s not how this self becomes rightly annihilated.

dn1:3.13.4.pli: Atthi kho, bho, añño attā sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā “ananto ākāso”ti ākāsānañcāyatanūpago.
dn1:3.13.4.eng: There is another self which has gone totally beyond perceptions of form. With the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that “space is infinite”, it’s reborn in the dimension of infinite space.
dn1:3.13.4.comm: Such a rebirth has left even the subtle body behind, becoming sheer consciousness. | The word āyatana is from a root meaning “expanse”. It is prominently used in this context, where it refers to a realm or “dimension” of rebirth, and in the analysis of sense experience, where it refers to a “field” of sense experience.

dn1:3.13.5.pli: Taṃ tvaṃ na jānāsi na passasi.
dn1:3.13.5.eng: You don’t know or see that.

dn1:3.13.6.eng: But I know it and see it.

dn1:3.13.7.pli: So kho, bho, attā yato kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā sammā samucchinno hotī’ti.
dn1:3.13.7.eng: Since this self is annihilated and destroyed when the body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death, that’s how this self becomes rightly annihilated.’
dn1:3.13.7.comm: This phrase appears incongruous as formless beings do not have a body. However the Chinese parallel at DA 21 does not mention kāya here, so it is likely to have arisen as an error in transmission where an earlier phrase was mistakenly copied.

dn1:3.13.8.pli: Ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti.
dn1:3.13.8.eng: That is how some assert the annihilation of an existing being.

dn1:3.14.2.eng: ‘That self of which you speak does exist, I don’t deny it.

dn1:3.14.3.pli: no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā sammā samucchinno hoti.
dn1:3.14.3.eng: But that’s not how this self becomes rightly annihilated.

dn1:3.14.4.pli: Atthi kho, bho, añño attā sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma “anantaṃ viññāṇan”ti viññāṇañcāyatanūpago.
dn1:3.14.4.eng: There is another self which has gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite space. Aware that “consciousness is infinite”, it’s reborn in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

dn1:3.14.5.eng: You don’t know or see that.

dn1:3.14.6.eng: But I know it and see it.
