dn1:3.14.7.eng: Since this self is annihilated and destroyed when the body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death, that’s how this self becomes rightly annihilated.’

dn1:3.14.8.pli: Ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti.
dn1:3.14.8.eng: That is how some assert the annihilation of an existing being.

dn1:3.15.1.eng: But someone else says to them:

dn1:3.15.2.pli: ‘atthi kho, bho, so attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi;
dn1:3.15.2.eng: ‘That self of which you speak does exist, I don’t deny it.

dn1:3.15.3.pli: no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā sammā samucchinno hoti.
dn1:3.15.3.eng: But that’s not how this self becomes rightly annihilated.

dn1:3.15.4.pli: Atthi kho, bho, añño attā sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma “natthi kiñcī”ti ākiñcaññāyatanūpago.
dn1:3.15.4.eng: There is another self that has gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness. Aware that “there is nothing at all”, it’s been reborn in the dimension of nothingness.

dn1:3.15.5.pli: Taṃ tvaṃ na jānāsi na passasi.
dn1:3.15.5.eng: You don’t know or see that.

dn1:3.15.6.eng: But I know it and see it.

dn1:3.15.7.pli: So kho, bho, attā yato kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā sammā samucchinno hotī’ti.
dn1:3.15.7.eng: Since this self is annihilated and destroyed when the body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death, that’s how this self becomes rightly annihilated.’

dn1:3.15.8.pli: Ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti.
dn1:3.15.8.eng: That is how some assert the annihilation of an existing being.

dn1:3.16.1.eng: But someone else says to them:

dn1:3.16.2.pli: ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi;
dn1:3.16.2.eng: ‘That self of which you speak does exist, I don’t deny it.

dn1:3.16.3.pli: no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā sammā samucchinno hoti.
dn1:3.16.3.eng: But that’s not how this self becomes rightly annihilated.

dn1:3.16.4.pli: Atthi kho, bho, añño attā sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma “santametaṃ paṇītametan”ti nevasaññānāsaññāyatanūpago.
dn1:3.16.4.eng: There is another self that has gone totally beyond the dimension of nothingness. Aware that “this is peaceful, this is sublime”, it’s been reborn in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
dn1:3.16.4.comm: The extension of the normal description of this state with the phrase “this is peaceful, this is sublime” is found only here and at AN 10.99:35.1.

dn1:3.16.5.pli: Taṃ tvaṃ na jānāsi na passasi.
dn1:3.16.5.eng: You don’t know or see that.

dn1:3.16.6.eng: But I know it and see it.

dn1:3.16.7.pli: So kho, bho, attā yato kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā sammā samucchinno hotī’ti.
dn1:3.16.7.eng: Since this self is annihilated and destroyed when the body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death, that’s how this self becomes rightly annihilated.’

dn1:3.16.8.pli: Ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti.
dn1:3.16.8.eng: That is how some assert the annihilation of an existing being.

dn1:3.17.1.pli: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā ucchedavādā sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi.
dn1:3.17.1.eng: These are the seven grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins assert the annihilation, eradication, and nonexistence of an existing being.

dn1:3.17.2.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ucchedavādā sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva sattahi vatthūhi …
dn1:3.17.2.eng: Any ascetics and brahmins who assert the annihilation, eradication, and nonexistence of an existing being do so on one or other of these seven grounds. Outside of this there is none.

dn1:3.18.2.pli: yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
dn1:3.18.2.eng: And those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.

dn1:3.19.0.eng: 3.2.5. Extinguishment of Suffering in This Life

dn1:3.19.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi.
dn1:3.19.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who speak of extinguishment in this life. They assert ultimate extinguishment for an existing being in this life on five grounds.
dn1:3.19.1.comm: These five theories argue for the extinguishment of suffering through the experience of pleasure in the present life. The Buddha taught extinguishment (nibbāna) in this very life, but not “of an existing being” (sato sattassa) or “self” (attā). The Buddha denied that there is such a thing, pointing out that we are a stream of ever-changing conditions, fueled by desire and attachment, and liable to suffering. With the end of craving there is no fuel to sustain the stream, so suffering comes to an end. | It is unclear why these views of the “present life” (diṭṭhadhamma) are classified under views of the future; see MN 102:2.8.

dn1:3.19.2.pli: Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi?
dn1:3.19.2.eng: And what are the five grounds on which they rely?

dn1:3.20.1.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā evaṃvādī hoti evaṃdiṭṭhi:
dn1:3.20.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

dn1:3.20.2.pli: ‘yato kho, bho, ayaṃ attā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hotī’ti.
dn1:3.20.2.eng: ‘When this self amuses itself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation, that’s how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in this life.’

dn1:3.20.3.eng: That is how some assert ultimate extinguishment for an existing being in this life.

dn1:3.21.1.eng: But someone else says to them:

dn1:3.21.2.pli: ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi;
dn1:3.21.2.eng: ‘That self of which you speak does exist, I don’t deny it.

dn1:3.21.3.pli: no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hoti.
dn1:3.21.3.eng: But that’s not how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in this life.

dn1:3.21.5.pli: Kāmā hi, bho, aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā, tesaṃ vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā.
dn1:3.21.5.eng: Because sensual pleasures are impermanent, suffering, and perishable. Their decay and perishing give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
dn1:3.21.5.comm: Here we see the philosophical reasoning that prompts the evolution of more refined conceptions of self.

dn1:3.21.6.pli: Yato kho, bho, ayaṃ attā vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hotī’ti.
dn1:3.21.6.eng: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, this self enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. That’s how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in this life.’
dn1:3.21.6.comm: The “absorptions” (jhāna) are central to Buddhist meditation. The Buddha did say that they can be considered “extinguishment in the present life” in a qualified sense (AN 9.51). As we have seen above, however, if they are undertaken with wrong view, the experience itself will tend to reinforce the attachment to a self.

dn1:3.21.7.eng: That is how some assert ultimate extinguishment for an existing being in this life.

dn1:3.22.1.eng: But someone else says to them:

dn1:3.22.2.pli: ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi;
dn1:3.22.2.eng: ‘That self of which you speak does exist, I don’t deny it.

dn1:3.22.3.pli: no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hoti.
dn1:3.22.3.eng: But that’s not how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in this life.
dn1:3.22.3.comm: The theorist has an experience of a deeper state of meditation, so they know that the first jhāna cannot be the ultimate.

dn1:3.22.5.pli: Yadeva tattha vitakkitaṃ vicāritaṃ, etenetaṃ oḷārikaṃ akkhāyati.
dn1:3.22.5.eng: Because the placing of the mind and the keeping it connected there are coarse.
dn1:3.22.5.comm: Jhānas are subtle states of refined consciousness in which nothing is coarse when compared to ordinary consciousness. Within each state, however, certain mental factors are coarse relative to others. A meditator proceeds through the jhānas with the successive stilling of the relatively coarser factors in each state.

dn1:3.22.6.pli: Yato kho, bho, ayaṃ attā vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hotī’ti.
dn1:3.22.6.eng: But when the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, this self enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected. That’s how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in this life.’

dn1:3.22.7.eng: That is how some assert ultimate extinguishment for an existing being in this life.

dn1:3.23.1.eng: But someone else says to them:

dn1:3.23.2.pli: ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi;
dn1:3.23.2.eng: ‘That self of which you speak does exist, I don’t deny it.

dn1:3.23.3.pli: no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hoti.
dn1:3.23.3.eng: But that’s not how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in this life.

dn1:3.23.5.pli: Yadeva tattha pītigataṃ cetaso uppilāvitattaṃ, etenetaṃ oḷārikaṃ akkhāyati.
dn1:3.23.5.eng: Because the rapture and emotional elation there are coarse.

dn1:3.23.6.pli: Yato kho, bho, ayaṃ attā pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati, sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti “upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī”ti, tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hotī’ti.
dn1:3.23.6.eng: But with the fading away of rapture, this self enters and remains in the third absorption, where it meditates with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, “Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss”. That’s how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in this life.’

dn1:3.23.7.eng: That is how some assert ultimate extinguishment for an existing being in this life.

dn1:3.24.1.eng: But someone else says to them:

dn1:3.24.2.pli: ‘atthi kho, bho, eso attā, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, neso natthīti vadāmi;
dn1:3.24.2.eng: ‘That self of which you speak does exist, I don’t deny it.

dn1:3.24.3.pli: no ca kho, bho, ayaṃ attā ettāvatā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hoti.
dn1:3.24.3.eng: But that’s not how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in this life.

dn1:3.24.5.pli: Yadeva tattha sukhamiti cetaso ābhogo, etenetaṃ oḷārikaṃ akkhāyati.
dn1:3.24.5.eng: Because the mental partaking of that as ‘blissful’ is said to be coarse.
dn1:3.24.5.comm: Ābhoga (“partaking”) is unique in the early texts in this sense. The commentary says that after emerging from jhāna, one repeatedly partakes and attends to that bliss (for ābhoga with manasikāra, see Mil 5.1.1:8.3). Compare Patañjalī’s commentary on Yogasūtra 1.17: “vitarka is the gross (sthula) partaking in the mental object, vicāra is subtle”.

dn1:3.24.6.pli: Yato kho, bho, ayaṃ attā sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṃ attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hotī’ti.
dn1:3.24.6.eng: But with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, this self enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. That’s how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in this life.’

dn1:3.24.7.eng: That is how some assert ultimate extinguishment for an existing being in this life.

dn1:3.25.1.pli: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi.
dn1:3.25.1.eng: These are the five grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins assert ultimate extinguishment for an existing being in this life.

dn1:3.25.2.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva pañcahi vatthūhi …
dn1:3.25.2.eng: Any ascetics and brahmins who assert ultimate extinguishment for an existing being in this life do so on one or other of these five grounds. Outside of this there is none.
dn1:3.25.2.comm: It is not clear why the still more subtle states of the formless attainments are not included here.

dn1:3.26.2.pli: yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
dn1:3.26.2.eng: And those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.

dn1:3.27.1.pli: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparantakappikā aparantānudiṭṭhino aparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi.
dn1:3.27.1.eng: These are the forty-four grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the final end assert various hypotheses concerning the final end.

dn1:3.27.2.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā aparantakappikā aparantānudiṭṭhino aparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva catucattārīsāya vatthūhi …
dn1:3.27.2.eng: Any ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the final end do so on one or other of these forty-four grounds. Outside of this there is none.

dn1:3.28.2.pli: yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
dn1:3.28.2.eng: And those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.

dn1:3.29.1.pli: Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā ca aparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi.
dn1:3.29.1.eng: These are the sixty-two grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the first beginning and the final end assert various hypotheses concerning the first beginning and the final end.

dn1:3.29.2.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā pubbantakappikā vā aparantakappikā vā pubbantāparantakappikā vā pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena; natthi ito bahiddhā.
dn1:3.29.2.eng: Any ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the first beginning or the final end do so on one or other of these sixty-two grounds. Outside of this there is none.

dn1:3.30.2.pli: ‘ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānā evaṅgahitā evaṃparāmaṭṭhā evaṅgatikā bhavanti evaṃabhisamparāyā’ti.
dn1:3.30.2.eng: ‘If you hold on to and attach to these grounds for views it leads to such and such a destiny in the next life.’
dn1:3.30.2.comm: Even the views of annihilation or extinguishment lead to rebirth, contrary to the beliefs of those who hold them.

dn1:3.30.3.pli: Tañca tathāgato pajānāti, tato ca uttaritaraṃ pajānāti, tañca pajānanaṃ na parāmasati, aparāmasato cassa paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā.
dn1:3.30.3.eng: He understands this, and what goes beyond this. And since he does not misapprehend that understanding, he has realized quenching within himself.

dn1:3.30.4.pli: Vedanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā anupādāvimutto, bhikkhave, tathāgato.
dn1:3.30.4.eng: Having truly understood the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape from feelings, the Realized One is freed through not grasping.

dn1:3.31.1.pli: Ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
dn1:3.31.1.eng: These are the principles—deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute—which the Realized One makes known after realizing them with his own insight. And those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.

dn1:3.32.0.1.eng: 4. The Grounds For Assertions About the Self and the Cosmos

dn1:3.32.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
dn1:3.32.1.eng: Now, these things are only the feeling of those who do not know or see, the anxiety and evasiveness of those under the sway of craving. Namely, when those ascetics and brahmins assert that the self and the cosmos are eternal on four grounds …
dn1:3.32.1.comm: Here the Buddha brings to the fore the notion of feelings which has been briefly mentioned throughout the text. Views are not objective descriptions of the world, but responses to our innermost needs. The word paritassita (“anxiety”) conveys both fear and desire, while vipphandita (“evasiveness”) captures how attachment to theorizing serves as an avoidance strategy.

dn1:3.33.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.

dn1:3.34.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
dn1:3.34.1.eng: finite or infinite on four grounds …

dn1:3.35.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
dn1:3.35.1.eng: or they resort to flip-flops on four grounds …

dn1:3.36.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
dn1:3.36.1.eng: or they assert that the self and the cosmos arose anomalously on two grounds …

dn1:3.37.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā pubbantānudiṭṭhino pubbantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
dn1:3.37.1.eng: they theorize about the first beginning on these eighteen grounds …

dn1:3.38.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ saññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti soḷasahi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
dn1:3.38.1.eng: or they assert that the self lives on after death in a percipient form on sixteen grounds …

dn1:3.39.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ asaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
dn1:3.39.1.eng: or that the self lives on after death in a non-percipient form on eight grounds …

dn1:3.40.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṃ nevasaññīnāsaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
dn1:3.40.1.eng: or that the self lives on after death in a neither percipient nor non-percipient form on eight grounds …

dn1:3.41.1.eng: or they assert the annihilation of an existing being on seven grounds …

dn1:3.42.1.eng: or they assert ultimate extinguishment for an existing being in this life on five grounds …

dn1:3.43.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparantakappikā aparantānudiṭṭhino aparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
dn1:3.43.1.eng: they theorize about the final end on these forty-four grounds …

dn1:3.44.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā ca aparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi, tadapi tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ ajānataṃ apassataṃ vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ paritassitavipphanditameva.
dn1:3.44.1.eng: When those ascetics and brahmins theorize about the first beginning and the final end on these sixty-two grounds, these things are only the feeling of those who do not know or see, the anxiety and evasiveness of those under the sway of craving.

dn1:3.45.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
dn1:3.45.1.eng: Now, these things are dependent on contact. Namely, when those ascetics and brahmins assert that the self and the cosmos are eternal on four grounds …
dn1:3.45.1.comm: The analysis is introducing more elements of dependent origination. The famous twelve links say that contact is the condition for feeling, which in turn causes craving.

dn1:3.57.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā ca aparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi, tadapi phassapaccayā.
dn1:3.57.1.eng: When those ascetics and brahmins theorize about the first beginning and the final end on these sixty-two grounds, that too is dependent on contact.

dn1:3.65.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā, uddhamāghātanaṃ asaññiṃ attānaṃ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṃvedissantīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.

dn1:3.70.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā ca aparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṃvedissantīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
dn1:3.70.1.eng: Now, when those ascetics and brahmins theorize about the first beginning and the final end on these sixty-two grounds, it is not possible that they should experience these things without contact.
dn1:3.70.1.comm: The text repeats all, but I abbreviate for legibility. In the oral tradition, extensive repetitions serve to reinforce the learning and ensure reliability of transmission. More subtly, they also help deepen understanding and contemplation. After reciting the extensive and complex treatment of the sixty-two views, the reciter takes the time to go over them again and again, letting them settle and consolidate. True learning takes time, but the repetitions that are reflective and reassuring in recitation become irksome and ponderous in reading.

dn1:3.71.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā …pe…

dn1:3.71.12.pli: yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā ca aparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi, sabbe te chahi phassāyatanehi phussa phussa paṭisaṃvedenti tesaṃ vedanāpaccayā taṇhā, taṇhāpaccayā upādānaṃ, upādānapaccayā bhavo, bhavapaccayā jāti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti.
dn1:3.71.12.eng: Now, when those ascetics and brahmins theorize about the first beginning and the final end on these sixty-two grounds, all of them experience this by repeated contact through the six fields of contact. Their feeling is a condition for craving. Craving is a condition for grasping. Grasping is a condition for continued existence. Continued existence is a condition for rebirth. Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.
dn1:3.71.12.comm: Finally the process of dependent origination, which has been foreshadowed little by little, is brought to its ultimate conclusion. The full twelve factors of dependent origination are not mentioned, but the process beginning with ignorance is implied throughout. Wrong view is a form of ignorance, and we have seen several examples of how such wrong views prompt intentional choices that generate consciousness in a new life.

dn1:3.72.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ayaṃ imehi sabbeheva uttaritaraṃ pajānāti.
dn1:3.72.1.eng: When a mendicant truly understands the six fields of contact’s origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape, they understand what lies beyond all these things.
dn1:3.72.1.comm: “Contact” (phassa) is the conjunction of the sense stimulus, the sense organ, and the associated consciousness.

dn1:3.72.2.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā pubbantakappikā vā aparantakappikā vā pubbantāparantakappikā vā pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi antojālīkatā, ettha sitāva ummujjamānā ummujjanti, ettha pariyāpannā antojālīkatāva ummujjamānā ummujjanti.
dn1:3.72.2.eng: All of these ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the first beginning or the final end are trapped in the net of these sixty-two grounds, so that wherever they emerge they are caught and trapped in this very net.
dn1:3.72.2.comm: They cannot see a way past attachment so long as they theorize in terms of an existing self.

dn1:3.72.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dakkho kevaṭṭo vā kevaṭṭantevāsī vā sukhumacchikena jālena parittaṃ udakadahaṃ otthareyya. Tassa evamassa: ‘ye kho keci imasmiṃ udakadahe oḷārikā pāṇā, sabbe te antojālīkatā. Ettha sitāva ummujjamānā ummujjanti; ettha pariyāpannā antojālīkatāva ummujjamānā ummujjantī’ti;
dn1:3.72.3.eng: Suppose a deft fisherman or his apprentice were to cast a fine-meshed net over a small pond. They’d think: ‘Any sizable creatures in this pond will be trapped in the net. Wherever they emerge they are caught and trapped in this very net.’
dn1:3.72.3.comm: The title is explained with a vivid simile. The Buddha was a master of observation, and constantly drew from everyday experience to illustrate his teachings. The metaphor works on a surface level to illustrate how theorists are trapped. But it also conveys something deeper, a sense of pathos and empathy with the helpless creatures who have no idea why they suffer.

dn1:3.72.4.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā pubbantakappikā vā aparantakappikā vā pubbantāparantakappikā vā pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi antojālīkatā ettha sitāva ummujjamānā ummujjanti, ettha pariyāpannā antojālīkatāva ummujjamānā ummujjanti.
dn1:3.72.4.eng: In the same way, all of these ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the first beginning or the final end are trapped in the net of these sixty-two grounds, so that wherever they emerge they are caught and trapped in this very net.

dn1:3.73.1.eng: The Realized One’s body remains, but his leash to existence has been cut off.
dn1:3.73.1.comm: The Buddha is not his body, which is merely the remnant of past kamma. | The bhavanetti is “that which leads to continued existence”. Early Sanskrit netrī always retains the expected grammatical sense, a noun from the root “to lead”, i.e. a “leader” (Rig Veda 1.113.4, 4.56.2, 5.50.2, 7.76.6, 7.77.2). Compare the English concept of the psychopomp or ferryman who leads you to the afterlife. Here, the commentary explains, “It is a name for craving. For by it beings are bound in their heart and lead on to life after life, like an ox tethered by the throat.” This suggests the sense of “lead” as in “leash”, which fits the metaphor of “cutting off”.

dn1:3.73.2.pli: Yāvassa kāyo ṭhassati, tāva naṃ dakkhanti devamanussā.
dn1:3.73.2.eng: As long as his body remains he will be seen by gods and humans.

dn1:3.73.3.pli: Kāyassa bhedā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā na naṃ dakkhanti devamanussā.
dn1:3.73.3.eng: But when his body breaks up, after life has ended, gods and humans will see him no more.

dn1:3.73.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ambapiṇḍiyā vaṇṭacchinnāya yāni kānici ambāni vaṇṭapaṭibandhāni, sabbāni tāni tadanvayāni bhavanti;
dn1:3.73.4.eng: When the stalk of a bunch of mangoes is cut, all the mangoes attached to the stalk will follow along.
dn1:3.73.4.comm: This metaphor is found at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.36, where it refers to the separation of the self from the body at death.

dn1:3.73.5.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ucchinnabhavanettiko tathāgatassa kāyo tiṭṭhati,
dn1:3.73.5.eng: In the same way, the Realized One’s body remains, but his leash to existence has been cut off.

dn1:3.73.6.pli: yāvassa kāyo ṭhassati, tāva naṃ dakkhanti devamanussā,
dn1:3.73.6.eng: As long as his body remains he will be seen by gods and humans.

dn1:3.73.7.pli: kāyassa bhedā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā na naṃ dakkhanti devamanussā”ti.
dn1:3.73.7.eng: But when his body breaks up, after life has ended, gods and humans will see him no more.”

dn1:3.74.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn1:3.74.1.eng: When he had spoken, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,

dn1:3.74.2.pli: “acchariyaṃ, bhante, abbhutaṃ, bhante, ko nāmo ayaṃ, bhante, dhammapariyāyo”ti?
dn1:3.74.2.eng: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing! What is the name of this exposition of the teaching?”

dn1:3.74.3.pli: “Tasmātiha tvaṃ, ānanda, imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ atthajālantipi naṃ dhārehi, dhammajālantipi naṃ dhārehi, brahmajālantipi naṃ dhārehi, diṭṭhijālantipi naṃ dhārehi, anuttaro saṅgāmavijayotipi naṃ dhārehī”ti.
dn1:3.74.3.eng: “Well then, Ānanda, you may remember this exposition of the teaching as ‘The Net of Meaning’, or else ‘The Net of the Teaching’, or else ‘The Divine Net’, or else ‘The Net of Views’, or else ‘The Supreme Victory in Battle’.”
dn1:3.74.3.comm: It is not uncommon to find multiple names for the same sutta, and here we see this practice originated with the Buddha himself. When is referred to by name at SN 41.3:2.4 and Kd 1:1.8.8, however, it is always called the Brahmajāla. It is also referred to by the list of views, numbered as sixty-three at Snp 3.6:42.1 and sixty at SN 8.2:5.1 = Thag 21.1:9.1.

dn1:3.74.4.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

dn1:3.74.5.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
dn1:3.74.5.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

dn1:3.74.6.pli: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne dasasahassī lokadhātu akampitthāti.
dn1:3.74.6.eng: And while this discourse was being spoken, the ten-thousandfold galaxy shook.
